reviewText:
Keep in mind that this game was initially a Nintendo 3DS game that was ported to console and PC after the fact. The graphics and animations might seem a little dated because of this. That being said, this port is not bad at all, at least for PC. The graphic quality resembles Resident Evil 4.

Gameplay and controls are very well done. It's 3rd person over the shoulder. Campaign is singleplayer only but you will have an AI partner. Your partner... isn't the best or most helpful, but thankfully they won't cause a game over if they get hit too much and sometimes serve as a nice distraction, except on bosses. Difficulty ranges from easy early on and nicely becomes more challenging toward the end.

There is one glaring problem with the gameplay though. The dodge mechanic is incredibly shoddy. On a 360 controller, you're supposed to press A and a direction at the same time to avoid an attack at the right time, but it only ever seemed to work half the time I did it. Either it's broken or the timing needs to be perfect, but it's very frustrating. I also had an incredible amount of frustration with 2 of the Bosses in this game due to their rather odd mechanics, one of which isn't helped by the wonky dodging.

This game is a LITTLE short, but that's forgivable since it was initially a 3DS game. It's also broken up into 14 episodes, some of which are very short. It also makes the game feel disjointed, because you'll be flashing back to earlier events a lot. It's mostly non linear on the ship later on in the game once you progress, so you can go back and find different weapons, ammo, health, and weapon mods (the weapons and the different mods are a great aspect to this game).

The game's story is very interesting with a nice plot twist. You'll be playing and partnering with a bunch of very interesting new and returning characters, with Jill Valentine the one you'll be playing the most and the only one who can access the weapons and mods you find.

Side note: I had an issue with the cutscenes having audio desync issues, but I'm not sure if this is only my issue.

Overall, if you're a Resident Evil fan, you're gonna want to play this game, as the story alone is worth it and captures the mood from the earlier games in the series, with some new elements as well as other elements from later games in the series. Other than that I recommend waiting until it is on sale if you want to play it. But you'll be getting your money's worth.

I haven't tried Raid Mode, but that may add some replay value if you're interested.

reviewText:
Pros:

-good atmosphere
-good storytelling
-replayability (raid mode)
-decent gameplay


Cons:

-somewhat outdated graphics (who cares)
-potentially short campaign (game timer says I beat it in about 6.5 hrs, my hours in-game are also from cutscenes and afking)
-survival element is not as heavy as it is in other RE games
-dodge mechanic (doesn't work half of the time but can be abused if you figure out how to use it)
-the biometric scanner (used to scan for otherwise unobtainable ammo and to collect data from defeated foes, which is then used to make an herb [lol]; overall a gimmicky feature)
-jill valentine remodel


I rate 6.5/10, get anyway if you are RE fan or it's on sale

reviewText:
To be precise, a side story of Resident Evil series, with classic taste and scenario.

A good game, but not as awesome as Resident Evil 1, 2, 3 (well, at least it's not all action-packed like Resident Evil 5 and 6). I still like it, as an another adventure featured old people from original Resident Evil series. One more positive point, Raid mode, which is pretty indentical with Mercenary mode in Resident Evil 3, supports co-op gameplay and tons of hard-to-earn achievements.

Good job Capcom, but next time, we need something better than this.

reviewText:
I was skeptical considering the Resident Evil games Capcom has been putting out lately that aren't even close to being considered Survival Horror."

This game turned out great though.

Resident Evil Revelations is episodic so you play as different characters throughout the game.

The episodes that featured Jill or Chris were excellent.

The episodes that featured the side characters just felt a bit lacking
date:
but seemed important for delivering pieces of the story to the player.

Ultimately I enjoyed this game.  Heavily preferred over RE:6 and Operation Racoon City....

I recommend a game-pad for playing this game.

Pros: Excellent PC Port.  Game looks fantastic.
The segments of the game that feature Jill are excellent and feel like the old school Resident Evil games with improved controls.
Portions of the game have the "Survival Horror" vibe.
Controls felt good. 3rd person shooter
Raid mode is fun to play long after the game is finished.  Repackages segments of the game world as new levels for the player to work their way through as they level up their characters and equipment.Cons: Episodes that move away from Jill interrupt the build-up of the Survival Horror experience with light-hearted comedic moments
If you don't use an Xbox360 Controller you will likely need a modification to use your preferred game-pad with the game.
8/10  Worth it if you enjoy Resident Evil
recommended: Jill Valentine and 3rd person action shooters"

reviewText:
Resident Evil Revelations is mostly based on a cruise ship that becomes a watery grave that no one swims away from.

And that is why I like this game. It's not like your other typical RE games that are mainly in a know-it's-for-sure this environment. The main storyline mostly focus on this ship, though there are instances where it is other areas that are not related to this ship.

Capcom has done well in making this game enjoyable. OST that are slow and gloomy which subtly fits into a dead-sea, and I think, have built enough attention onto this ship that have not lost it's main focus on.

Glad that I bought this :)
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This reminds me alot of the PSX Resident Evil games, where there is a nice mix of action and puzzle solving to move towards your objecive. The story is a step above the psx classics, due to some interesting twists in the plot.

I'm playing these in order, so I previously finished Resident Evil 4 and the next one I'll tackle is Resident Evil 5.

Revelations has the AI Co-oP buddy system used from Resident Evil 5, Its not 100% helpful but it assists when it can. Its not perfect, but it helps. Thankfully its not needed for the most crucial of moments that can break a game, all because the AI Co-op partner was lacking to assist.

Since this is a HD remake of a Nintendo 3DS title, many say the graphics are low/2004-ish. It does the job well and did'nt annoy me at all while playing it.

To buy or avoid?

If you like Resident Evil, you'll probably already have this
If you are starting out into Resident Evil, this is a good buy when it is on sale, since it can go as low as 75% off.

reviewText:
After beating Resident Evil Revelations on all difficulty levels, spending more than 100 hours in Raid Mode and beating almost all stages (Ghost Ship, why you are so hard?) I think I earned myself a right to write this review.

For the starters I want to say that I'm big fan of Resident Evil franchise. I remember how scared I was as kid playing first Resident Evil game on Playstation console. I had tons of fun and scary jumps and even after so many years old Resident Evil games can scare me to death. I saw fall down of Resident Evil games when the sixth main entry in franchise was released yet I still remained a fan of it. It's part of my life, and even with so many terrible routes it had taken, nothing will change that. So this review might be kind of biased, full of comparisons to other Resident Evil games, if you want a review that will be made from normal gamer and not life for fan of series, please stop reading it. Thank you.

reviewText:
I originally played Resident Evil Revelations on the 3ds but i didn't play it for long due to the small screen of the 3ds (don't have the 3ds XL), than a year after it releases on consoles and pc so i decided to purchase it. It is a really good port overall i really enjoyed playing it on the big screen and the graphics look really nice, capcom did a great job with this addition to the series.

So I myself have played just about all of the resident evil games and i have to say I am a huge fan of this series although in my opinion resident evil 5 was a bit of of a disappointment, (it didn't feel like a resident evil game).Revelations was a lot of fun it had a good story with some of our favorite characters returning like Jill Valentine and Chris Redfield and some new characters like Parker Luciani, Jessica Sherawat, Keith Lumley and etc.

Pros:
New Game plus mode
Extra story difficulty level
Raid Mode multiplayer
Great HD Graphics

Cons:
Limited customization
A short Story
No ZOMBIES!!
Gear Grinding in raid mode

Overall
As a resident evil fan I enjoyed this game a lot, it may have had a bit of a short story but i still managed to enjoy it and it still has that raid mode mode that you can play solo or run through with a friend as well, I highly recommend this game for the fans of the series and for the newcomers to the series as well.

reviewText: This is actually a really good game, far better than RE6. Revelations has that familiar Resident Evil feel, while maintaining it's action-horror blend. It has some minor flaws like repetitive animations, a few poor quality environment textures and the lack of local/campaign co-op, but it's the raid mode that you will keep coming back for. I smashed this game for countless hours on my playstation 3, and during the holiday steam sales i couldn't resist a pc copy so now i can play raid mode during down time at work!!! :)
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Yeah, have to agree pretty much with most of the other reviews for this game, the closest thing to RE1-3 in a 3d / RE4 style game you'll get. The graphics / FMV are lush in places but show there 3DS origins in places, the controls are tight (as far as an RE game is concerned) and the most importantly the gameplay is nice.

The main reason the gameplay is good is because of the even pacing between item finding / scaning, light puzzling and exploration mixed in with the combat. Also you 'WILL' have to watch the ammo as you'd expect in a true survival horror and the best thing is the main setting is spot on, the ship is very reminiscent of RE1's mansion even in puzzle / interaction elements and the light backtracking required to unlock a weapon or open that room previously locked by a symboled key, love it, feels like a true RE game in 3d clothing for me, keep on this route Capcom!

PS. Oh +1 also for the return of Jill's original nose, now we just need some silent audio moments and static cams to bring back the fear factor.

reviewText:
To be precise, a side story of Resident Evil series, with classic taste and scenario.

A good game, but not as awesome as Resident Evil 1, 2, 3 (well, at least it's not all action-packed like Resident Evil 5 and 6). I still like it, as an another adventure featured old people from original Resident Evil series. One more positive point, Raid mode, which is pretty indentical with Mercenary mode in Resident Evil 3, supports co-op gameplay and tons of hard-to-earn achievements.

Good job Capcom, but next time, we need something better than this.

reviewText:
Resident Evil Revelations is mostly based on a cruise ship that becomes a watery grave that no one swims away from.

And that is why I like this game. It's not like your other typical RE games that are mainly in a know-it's-for-sure this environment. The main storyline mostly focus on this ship, though there are instances where it is other areas that are not related to this ship.

Capcom has done well in making this game enjoyable. OST that are slow and gloomy which subtly fits into a dead-sea, and I think, have built enough attention onto this ship that have not lost it's main focus on.

Glad that I bought this :)

After beating Resident Evil Revelations on all difficulty levels, spending more than 100 hours in Raid Mode and beating almost all stages (Ghost Ship, why you are so hard?) I think I earned myself a right to write this review.

For the starters I want to say that I'm big fan of Resident Evil franchise. I remember how scared I was as kid playing first Resident Evil game on Playstation console. I had tons of fun and scary jumps and even after so many years old Resident Evil games can scare me to death. I saw fall down of Resident Evil games when the sixth main entry in franchise was released yet I still remained a fan of it. It's part of my life, and even with so many terrible routes it had taken, nothing will change that. So this review might be kind of biased, full of comparisons to other Resident Evil games, if you want a review that will be made from normal gamer and not life for fan of series, please stop reading it. Thank you.

reviewText:
I wholeheartedly recommend this game. The main campaign was fun to play and the story was interesting to follow. The level design is nice - most of the game takes place on a cruise ship, and the designers keep you revisiting old areas by using different keys to access new rooms and content. After you beat the regular story mode, you can continue to revisit the areas in a Raid mode, where you have different stages with increasingly levelled enemies. This Raid mode I found to be quite fun, but I feel you need to do a bit of grinding to level up properly and to have enough currency to upgrade your gear.

Controls are okay, I've played with keyboard and a mouse - for some reason strafing is incredibly slow, unlike in other games. The graphics are nice to look at and I was able to get a solid 60 fps on a mid-range laptop, so the presentation was very smooth.

I probably won't be replaying the story mode again, but I feel I got my money's worth out of Resident Evil: Revelations.

reviewText:
The days of the old gritty mysterious Resident Evil are over and I will miss them...BUT as much as I do, I think
the franchise took a step forward in the right direction with Revelations at least for the meantime. Storytelling is episodic and gameplay is what you would expect from any other resident evil game with a twist of action, you get to play as many different characters on many different missions folding into eachother to tell this decent and very interesting Resident Evil story.

Theres even a Raid Mode" that you can unlock by playing the entire 8 to 10 hour campaign. Raid Mode will have you run through familiar terrain killing water zombies with large health bars for rank
hoursPlayed: BP and EXP. You can play with a friend or test yourself. I would say this is the equivelant of Zombies in COD.\n\nI give this game a 7/10 for its decent story and familiar gameplay with the addition of Raid Mode and New Game+. Hopefully in the very near future the franchise will start making newer Resident Evils with the originals in complete thought."

reviewText: This game is phonomenal! The campaign is absolutely survival-horror, it's actually the best survival-horror game I've ever played. You're outnumbered by creatures you've never even seen before, and trying to escape the Queen Zenobia (it's set on an abandoned ship) alive. This definetely gave me a good couple of scares, and some of the creatures you'll encounter will seriously creep you out (Rachel, anyone?). After you've finished the campaign, you can start a new game+, which allows you to replay the game with all your current gear, to relive the horror once more. There are 30 handprints to find throughout the campaign, which gives achievement hunters some satisfaction in searching. Once you're through the campaign, your fun has only begun; as there is also Raid Mode to accompany it. Raid Mode is a great multiplayer experience that allows you to go through sections of the game as stages, and each time you complete a stage you'll get new weapons and/or weapon parts, depending on how well you've done. There are a multitude of stages to do, as well as 3 difficulties to do them all in. If multiplayer isn't really your thing, you can do Raid Mode solo if you like. The price tag may be $50, but it is well worth it as you'll definetely clock in a considerable amount of hours. This is a great gmae to get if you're either looking to get into the Resident Evil series, find a good survival-horror game, or just want to have a really fun time. A must-buy :)

reviewText:
Port of a 3DS game, and yet it leaves me wondering: why? Not to mention that it is actually priced *higher* than Resident Evil 6 (despite 6 having more content, higher production value, and (arguably) more thought behind it).

Okay, some things I liked. Keeping in mind that it was a port of a mobile game, it actually looks pretty good at times. The weapon customisation, while not stellar, was still pretty nice. Raid mode is also pretty nice, if you like grindfests (I do).

But really, people tout this game as returning to the roots of the series, which I certainly think it tried to do, but it just falls short. Why? Ammunition is plentiful, sense of dread and the fear of what lies around the corner is gone, puzzles are pretty much nonexistant, no inventory management to speak of and decisions of fight or flight are never really made.

That's just comparing it to the classic games, mind you.

On top of that, I think there's a lot of wasted potential here. I was excited for the game mainly because of two things: the setting and the enemies. I thought the setting would be perfect, combining survival horror with dreaded underwater segements, creating a truly fiendish monster of a game. I also thought the enemies were kind of wierd and abstract looking, and I thought a lot could be done with underwater creatures affected with a new kind of virus.

What you get instead is a very straightforward corridor shooter. The enemies are basically reskinned zombies (regular zombies, strong zombie, zombie with a gun, fat zombie etc.) and the underwater segments are actually few and far between. Not to mention the underwater segments are *less* scary than the dry segments, thanks to a Mario 64"-like water-surfacing-health-regeneration system.

The plot
recommended: is silly. But not only that
hoursPlayed: its just not entertaining. The voice acting is pretty questionable too. It's nice to see Chris Redfield back
voteText: looking & sounding like he does in RE5 and 6 (although it sounds a little like hes just phoning his performance in this time)

reviewText: Harkens a bit back to the older, scarier Resident Evil themes while maintaining gameplay that isn't itself harkening to 1996.  The campaign mode is engaging and well thought out with an Alan Wake-style episode system, constantly changing points of view, playable characters, and fleshing out more and more of the setting.  The Raid mode is bare bones until the campaign is unlocked; then, you get to work solo or with an ally using the roster from the main game in various maps with a good bit of challenge.  Not exactly worth full price (Steam is aiming high here) but $20 for the base game w/ DLC is a steal.

reviewText:
I can't help but feel that anyone who says this is a return to the series' roots is a clueless person who never completed any Resident Evil after 4 or any Resident Evil before 4... It's not bad, by any particular means outside of story and character dialog (it's not even cheesy, it's just very, very, very bad) but it sure as heck is NOT a return to its roots.

It's basically a mix of 5 and 6 with some aspects of 4, but only a tiny bit, thrown in for good measure. It has customizeable weapons similar to 4, it has terribly boring, generic and uncompelling enemies similar to 5, and the overall gunplay/damage/mindlessness of 6.

At fifty bucks this game is a total rip off, even with RAID mode and co-op (both of which do add a lot of fun to this otherwise terrible story and mediocre gameplay/enemies). It can be beat at very leisure 6 hours. Get it massively on sale and don't buy into the mindless hype. This is still a VERY modern Resident Evil and that isn't always a good thing. Play this then play Code Veronica or heck the remake of 1 and say this game is about horror. Sure, maybe the first episode, if that, but not much after it besides laughter and eyerolling.

Co-Op and RAID mode saves this game from a thumbs down, but just barely.

reviewText:
I perhaps expected too much having seen many people describe this as the best in the series since RE4 - a positive review but for me personally its a middling game. The game has its plus points.....Chris & Jill, Veltro, the general plot, the mansion-esque interiors of the ship, the underwater areas, weapon attachments, the Genesis (to a degree) and omission of the tank like controls, however, it lets itself down in several key areas.

Aside from Chris and Jill the other characters are hokey to say the least, *cough* Jackass? *cough*. Raymond and Jessica pick up some slack but are let down by exceptionally cheesey dialogue even for a RE game, this is widespread across all characters in RE:R. The episodic nature of the game hops and jumps around across characters/timelines/locations to the point where story and gameplay don't flow. The visuals whilst impressive for a handheld port on closer inspection reveal some awful looking textures. Gameplay elements such as the Genesis are initially fun but again personally I found it very apparent that this was something that was designed with a second screen in mind i.e. the second screen of a handheld or the controller screen of a Wii U. Genesis fealt pointless after the first few chapters, an idea that hadn't been fully realised, not even on the games lead platform which was a great shame as it would have been excellent usage of a secondary handheld screen.

It's an 8-10 hour campaign, it's enjoyable in spurts. It's not the modern day savior of the series as some people would have you believe, not even close. It's light on horror, heavy on gunplay and another game in the series which will divide fans.

reviewText:
Resident Evil: Revelations is a pretty decent Resident Evil game, following in the footsteps of Resident Evil 4 which changed how the series played.

+Campaign's an enjoyable ride of action and your run-of-the-mill zombie shooting.
+Gun customization allows you to utilize guns in both Raid and Campaign modes as you see fit.
+You see favorite characters returning followed by some new faces.
+Raid mode's a fun time killer with upgradable guns and rarities, but general experience grinding.
+Combat is standard RE4/RE5/RE6 fare.

-Story's kind of lacking and silly.
-The writing is pretty awkward at points (Me and my sweet ♥♥♥ are coming to save you!")
-Boss fights (except the final) were repetitive "kite the boss around the arena and shoot the weak point" fights.
-Don't expect an active playerbase with the Raid mode. Haven't found a player match yet.
-On normal

reviewText:
Resident Evil Revelations: King of Tedious Horror

Pros
+Good visuals! Surprising since this is a remaster from a 3DS game.
+It's closer to the style of the originals than the recent numbered releases.
+I actually liked the upgrade system for the guns. A lot of times you wouldn't have a lot of parts, so it made you think about what weapons you use the most, or what ones you had the most ammo for.

Cons
-Really clunky controls. Sad, but this is coming from a 3DS game. I even played with a controller, assuming that would help, but it really didn't.
-Story. An incident happens that you don't care about, so you try and cover it up for a corporation you don't care about, there was something about a city that I'm sure the citizens care about... Some boat no one cares about... For a brief period of time you play as two guys no one cares about... It's pretty impressive to not care this much. None of the new characters seem unique or interesting in the slightest, and as a result a LOT of this game feels like filler.
-Puzzles are tedious. Go here, collect this, suddenly a new area opens up, we get it.
-Enemies. Hint: Enemies aren't scary if they take a million shots to kill and your only threat is running out of ammo in a room where enemies infinitely respawn! That's just called annoying.

To be fair, there is a bit of lore between Chris and Jill that may be neat for a Resident Evil fan. For everyone else, avoid like the T-Virus.

reviewText:
Nice game, controls with the mouse and keyboard are much nicer than on the original 3DS layout. Even with the Pro Pad thing. It can sometimes stutter int he framerate at spots, usually when it's loading in a map, but smoothes back out a few seconds after.

The music and sounds are rather well done, too. In-game, everything has 3D positional surround. Only the FMVs seem to be in stereo.

Capcom could probably have spent a bit more time in effort on the textures and models, but overall it does have an increase compared to the original.

It's a shame that no one seems to be playing the RAID mode online anymore, though. So the co-op aspect seems dead in terms of random play online. got it during the 75% off deal, felt it was worthwhile for the cost even having 'conquered' it on the 3DS prior.

reviewText:
Having grown up with the earlier Resident Evils and suffering through the mess that was Resident Evil 5, I had little hope that Capcom could recover from the damage they've done to the franchise. But, hey, they thankfully proved me wrong with a game that was originally a 3DS spin off. With Revelations, the series once again gains survival horror like settings, atmosphere, and mechanics while still maintaining all the improvements made with the controls.

For the older fans: You'll get a decent amount of survival horror atmosphere, along with the ammo conservation mechanics. It's nowhere near the golden days of Resident Evil 1-CV but it's leagues above the stuff they pulled with Resident Evil 5. Heck, it's a start in the right direction right? The story as well actually feels like a throwback to the earlier games with a lot of chess moves going on in the background and you the player trying to figure out the mystery before the game reveals it. Of course most importantly, they brought the item chest back. I only serves to hold extra fire arms in this game but having inventory management in a RE game after such a long time, was a nice surprise.

For the newer fans: All the great things about Resident Evil 4's controls are still there, ammo isn't limited enough that you can't go on a small shooting spree on normal or lower difficulty, and action sequences are sprinkled through the entire game. So if you like the action side more of the franchise, you can have fun with Revelations with the understanding it's not 4 or 5 in terms of shooting everything that comes at you.

To wrap this up, this is a great game compared to the junk Capcom has released in the RE franchise these couple of years. Good story, exploration, running from enemies, good narrative, and interesting enemy designs(though they get repetitive after a while.) I hope Capcom lets the team behind this game continue to do their own thing of bringing back the series closer to its original form because fans will response to that with purchases. Meanwhile, Capcom can use the main series to continue to try and force a square peg in a round hole with their No

reviewText:
(This review does not include the raid mode, which is actually pretty fun with a friend initially but it wears off pretty quickly, if you plan to buy this just for coop, do not buy it. If you are however interested in its campaign do read on.)

In an era where the survival horror genre is ultimately boiled down to your average military shooter (or other ways to get it to become more mainstream), Resident Evil: Revelations manages to be faithful to its series roots in more ways than the series' recent iterations (including the worshipped 4).

RE:R is set mainly on an abandoned cruise ship infested with zombies. The idea of marrying RE to a ship setting is a match made in heaven. With closed and claustrophobic environments, the game will immediately invoke a sense of creepiness as to what lies on the other end of the door or when you turn a corner. While the zombies aren't very scary at all, the presentation of them and how they would appear in front of you is creepily perfect.

The story is almost predictable but plays out very nicely as the characters are interesting and mostly likable, including a very nice presentation of a chilling atmosphere.

However, it is debatable that the first half of the story is creepier due to the initial unfamiliarity of the setting as you are going to be revisiting familiar areas of the ship. Fortunately, the second half is more dense story-wise which gives it good reason for you to finish playing it.

One aspect which i could not vouch for is its gameplay; it is extremely outdated. While I do understand that it is a port from a 3DS game, as a PC game the mechanics of the game is very stiff and really feels dated. Since a huge chunk of the game consists mostly of gameplay, this takes alot of points away from it being an extremely good game. But for the most part it does give a survival horror vibe to it due to its constrains, but there are definitely better ways to do it.

Overall, Resident Evil: Revelations is an extremely solid game. It tells a pretty cliche story in a good way with its strong cast, great soundtrack, setting and atmosphere. Gameplay leaves alot to be desired and at times may be frustrating and really stiff.

7.5/10 I would actually give it somewhere in between 7.5 and 8 but i think its closer to 7.5

Also, if you are interested in butts, I recommend it fully. 10/10

reviewText:
(This review does not include the raid mode, which is actually pretty fun with a friend initially but it wears off pretty quickly, if you plan to buy this just for coop, do not buy it. If you are however interested in its campaign do read on.)

In an era where the survival horror genre is ultimately boiled down to your average military shooter (or other ways to get it to become more mainstream), Resident Evil: Revelations manages to be faithful to its series roots in more ways than the series' recent iterations (including the worshipped 4).

RE:R is set mainly on an abandoned cruise ship infested with zombies. The idea of marrying RE to a ship setting is a match made in heaven. With closed and claustrophobic environments, the game will immediately invoke a sense of creepiness as to what lies on the other end of the door or when you turn a corner. While the zombies aren't very scary at all, the presentation of them and how they would appear in front of you is creepily perfect.

The story is almost predictable but plays out very nicely as the characters are interesting and mostly likable, including a very nice presentation of a chilling atmosphere.

However, it is debatable that the first half of the story is creepier due to the initial unfamiliarity of the setting as you are going to be revisiting familiar areas of the ship. Fortunately, the second half is more dense story-wise which gives it good reason for you to finish playing it.

One aspect which i could not vouch for is its gameplay; it is extremely outdated. While I do understand that it is a port from a 3DS game, as a PC game the mechanics of the game is very stiff and really feels dated. Since a huge chunk of the game consists mostly of gameplay, this takes alot of points away from it being an extremely good game. But for the most part it does give a survival horror vibe to it due to its constrains, but there are definitely better ways to do it.

Overall, Resident Evil: Revelations is an extremely solid game. It tells a pretty cliche story in a good way with its strong cast, great soundtrack, setting and atmosphere. Gameplay leaves alot to be desired and at times may be frustrating and really stiff.

7.5/10 I would actually give it somewhere in between 7.5 and 8 but i think its closer to 7.5

Also, if you are interested in butts, I recommend it fully. 10/10

reviewText:
Resident Evil Revelations is the most recent RE game that, in my opinion, comes closest to the classic survival horror RE fans love.
I could do a massive in depth review, but I'll keep it short...I'll mention the atmosphere and the gameplay, though.

The atmosphere is done quite well in this game.
Most of this game is set on an abandoned cruise ship crawling with horrors. One of the strengths of RE is that they are able to bring any setting into the horror, and here it is no exception. I found myself genuinely creeped out by the many things on this haunted ship.
However I wish they didn't change settings during the course of the game. Because of flashbacks and attempts to advance the plot, the game sometimes changes its setting to a city on fire or a mountain range, which aren't quite as scary. But it's a fairly minor quibble, as this game still manages to overal creep the player out.

The gameplay is reminiscient of RE4 and RE5, with lots of shooting abound. But, I did appreciate the fact that ammo is actually quite limited in this gamel while past REs tend to have so much ammo you could go in guns blazing. This game, while it does have a noticeable amount of ammo, you had to be a bit careful in how much you were shooting. Granted, it isn't as scarce as in REmake, but go too trigger happy and you might just...well, die.

I could go more in depth, but I'll probably bore you all.
In the other fields, I think the music and plot do a decent job at what they need to do. (Granted, the plot here isn't the greatest, but it's RE - when were they ever realistic?)
I think overall, while this game didn't scare me as much as the early REs did, it does manage to stay true to its roots and give a great survival horror experience.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's no re4.

This game got a lot of praise for being more of a return to the roots of survival horror, bringing back the survival factor with ammo management and atmosphere and all that. It really didn't, the game wasn't scary and running out of ammo was never even close to being a problem. I also didn't like the hidden handprints, bringing out the genesis scanner to scan every single room slowing my walking speed down to a crawl was boring as ♥♥♥♥, finding objects such as medals hidden around a level as seen in previous re's was much more enjoyable.

That said, the game was alright. Shooting zombies was enjoyable enough, the mod system added some cool variety and the campaign didn't last too long. If you want an above average third person shooter, this could be it. Haven't tried out raid mode.

Hot tip: put infighter 3 and damage 7 on the M40A1 and no enemy will ever be a problem again.

reviewText: Revelations is a rather interesting part of the Resident Evil series. On one hand, it does feel like a side-story, not part of the main series. On the other, it often plays more like what Resident Evil used to be, than the newest entries. It feels like a more focused and better put together game, than Resident Evil 6 (released same year). But at the same time, doesn't evoke the same feelings, RE6 does, feels like designers lacked confidence and built the game by the checklist, not by their inner desires.\nBasic gameplay and the main parts of the game are really well done. Controls and some of the principles feel almost a perfect fit for a potential remake of the classic RE games, both in a more survival horror auto-aim style, and survival action over the shoulder more action style. Stuff no longer falls from enemies (escept for rare cases of mini-boss encounters, most of which can be skipped), ammo is rather scarce, running away is very often a very viable and even preferable option. Many locations are very narrow, but there is a rather well implemented dodge move, which is quite important to master. There's more freedom of exploration and good old hey I found a key

reviewText:
I really enjoyed this game but it's weirdly structured. The weapon customization is deep and addicting, finding mods and combining them in a way that suits your playstyle is 50% of the fun. There's a downside to this : the early game is quite boring as you face lots of bullet sponge enemies with nothing but a peashooter. The shotgun you get after that is slightly better but it still pales in comparison to other Resident Evil games. It takes a few hours before you start to get weapons that have a visible impact on your foes. I'd go as far as to say the core game loop of shooting and improving your guns doesn't get really fun until new game +/infernal difficulty. Infernal difficulty is very smartly done, adding monsters in new places so you really gotta stay on your toes and use every tool at your disposal. The game becomes slower paced and you start to notice the little things, like the dynamic music, cool animations...it feels like the right way to play. It's a shame because I think a lot of people stopped after one playthrough.

Random thoughts :

- Sidekicks need to go. They keep breaking the atmosphere by spouting out atrocious one liners, they deal virtually no damage and are immortal so you never care for them.
- Raid mode is really good if you're into skinner box type of gameplay
- I still don't know what the story's about
- Jill sounds like a burned-out mom

reviewText:
Great zombie killing 3rd person shooter with horror elements. Nice environments, though they may get repetitive if you plan to replay a lot. Some scenes are not advised for people under the age limit. Great character design and shapes, especially on Jill and Rachel, and particular bosses.

A lot of weapons and customization, character and weapon unlockables. Story is poor, like any other zombie game, there's outbreak, infection, bla-bla, we have to kill stuff and save earth. But what's important is the killing of things that are dead, because you don't really kill anything, because they are dead.

In this one you will mostly be on your own, in single player that is, usually you and your partner will be separated and occasionally meet up. In co-op mode however you play stages from selection of single player levels together with your friend, to clear the stage and not die. It's fun and may get boring after a while, like any repeatable thing, unless it's sex... well if you do 10-20 sexruns each day, you might get exhausted and also bored eventually. But don't get your hopes up that high, because there's rarely anyone that does that. Enjoy.

reviewText:
Any Resident Evil fan needs to play this!

When I first started Resident Evil Revelaitons, I didn't know what to expect. However, this game ended up being one of my favourites of the series.

As fans of the series will know, the Resident Evil series changed a great deal with Resident Evil 4. And although that was a great game, it felt very different from its predecessors.

Luckily, Revelaitons does a brilliant job of recapturing the feel and flavour of those classic Resident Evil games. The story may not be brilliant, but then again, the series was never renowned for its narrative. What's important is that Revelaitons gives a greater focus on delivering fear to the player, and the limited amount of ammunition forces you to pick your foes wisely.

For me, the original Resident Evil and Resident Evil Zero will remain my favourites of the series. Revelaitons, however, comes a close third.

True Resident Evil fans will appreciate the cheeky little nods to previous entries of the series in this fantastic game filled with unspeakable creatures which leave you with nothing to say except, what is this?""

reviewText:
Resident Evil Revelations is the most recent RE game that, in my opinion, comes closest to the classic survival horror RE fans love.
I could do a massive in depth review, but I'll keep it short...I'll mention the atmosphere and the gameplay, though.

The atmosphere is done quite well in this game.
Most of this game is set on an abandoned cruise ship crawling with horrors. One of the strengths of RE is that they are able to bring any setting into the horror, and here it is no exception. I found myself genuinely creeped out by the many things on this haunted ship.
However I wish they didn't change settings during the course of the game. Because of flashbacks and attempts to advance the plot, the game sometimes changes its setting to a city on fire or a mountain range, which aren't quite as scary. But it's a fairly minor quibble, as this game still manages to overal creep the player out.

The gameplay is reminiscient of RE4 and RE5, with lots of shooting abound. But, I did appreciate the fact that ammo is actually quite limited in this gamel while past REs tend to have so much ammo you could go in guns blazing. This game, while it does have a noticeable amount of ammo, you had to be a bit careful in how much you were shooting. Granted, it isn't as scarce as in REmake, but go too trigger happy and you might just...well, die.

I could go more in depth, but I'll probably bore you all.
In the other fields, I think the music and plot do a decent job at what they need to do. (Granted, the plot here isn't the greatest, but it's RE - when were they ever realistic?)
I think overall, while this game didn't scare me as much as the early REs did, it does manage to stay true to its roots and give a great survival horror experience.

reviewText:
What can I say about Resident Evil: Revelations ?

I bought the game during the Steam summer sale 2014 for 9,99€ and believe me when I say that this game is worth every single Euro of it, especially if you are a fan of the older Resident Evil titles. I almost regret it that I did not bought it earlier.

I do not know how much I can actually write about the game without spoiling it at least a little bit so be aware of it. You have been warned.

Capcom tried to get back to the roots with this game after the more action based Resident Evil 5 and 6.

Therefore you will encounter a lot less of the Call of Duty" feeling where you have to shoot your way through the levels. In addition to that there are no real quick time events either. However
date: there are some little passages within the game where you have to shoot your way through the monsters. Thankfully
recommended: these passages are rather short and do not ruin the game to much.\n\nYou play the game mainly as Jill Valentine who was sent out with her partner Parker Luciani to find Chris Redfield. Even though the main character is Jill you will have to play some different characters as well. The story might be confusing at first sight
hoursPlayed: because there are some jumps here and there
voteText: but it will all make sense in the end.\n\nThe biggest part of the game plays on a ship
helpfulPercent: which is huge by the way. During your progress you will unlock new rooms and areas of the ship and some of them are really pretty. You will need to backtrack a couple of times to get new keys etc. to open new areas so a good memory or good map reading skills are recommended otherwise you will run in circles =)\nThere are even some riddles in the game
votesHelpful: but sadly they are not really worth mentioning. Oh I almost forgot about the "shock moments". Some of them really catched me off guard. I really recommend to play this game with lights out in the evening
votesTotal: preferably with a good headset.\n\nI did my first playthrough on the normal difficulty and in comparison to Resident Evil 5 and 6 I actually managed to run out of ammo sometimes so do not waste you bullets. I can only imagine how brutal the hardest difficulty must be which I will definitely try to beat. By the way the last boss of the game really deserves to be called "boss". Personaly
votesFunny: I think it was one of the most hardest bossfights in my Resident Evil history. Maybe because I did not upgrade my weapons or did not use a rocket launcher (easy mode). Believe me you will be so much satisfied after you beat him words just cannot describe it. Dark Souls is a piece of cake in comparison

reviewText: This is one of those games where even the flaws are something you look over as being beauty marks. Raid mode makes it a game you can pick up and kill some time on any time you really want to, but because of raid mode you'll want to finish the story just to unlock more levels of raid mode. This is not to say the story is bad in any way, as many new characters such as Grinder and Jackass are interesting and funny characters that could easily be desearving of their own game. However Raid mode is a huge selling point. A good amount of the time you'll invest may be in finding your perfect gun, or the fastest route through a map or just trying to beat an old score. Normally grinding and leveling like that isn't for everyone but I feel like its something a lot of people would enjoy if they played it.\nTied with RE4 For favorite Resident evil game.

reviewText: Revelations is a rather interesting part of the Resident Evil series. On one hand, it does feel like a side-story, not part of the main series. On the other, it often plays more like what Resident Evil used to be, than the newest entries. It feels like a more focused and better put together game, than Resident Evil 6 (released same year). But at the same time, doesn't evoke the same feelings, RE6 does, feels like designers lacked confidence and built the game by the checklist, not by their inner desires.\nBasic gameplay and the main parts of the game are really well done. Controls and some of the principles feel almost a perfect fit for a potential remake of the classic RE games, both in a more survival horror auto-aim style, and survival action over the shoulder more action style. Stuff no longer falls from enemies (escept for rare cases of mini-boss encounters, most of which can be skipped), ammo is rather scarce, running away is very often a very viable and even preferable option. Many locations are very narrow, but there is a rather well implemented dodge move, which is quite important to master. There's more freedom of exploration and good old hey I found a key

reviewText:
Having grown up with the earlier Resident Evils and suffering through the mess that was Resident Evil 5, I had little hope that Capcom could recover from the damage they've done to the franchise. But, hey, they thankfully proved me wrong with a game that was originally a 3DS spin off. With Revelations, the series once again gains survival horror like settings, atmosphere, and mechanics while still maintaining all the improvements made with the controls.

For the older fans: You'll get a decent amount of survival horror atmosphere, along with the ammo conservation mechanics. It's nowhere near the golden days of Resident Evil 1-CV but it's leagues above the stuff they pulled with Resident Evil 5. Heck, it's a start in the right direction right? The story as well actually feels like a throwback to the earlier games with a lot of chess moves going on in the background and you the player trying to figure out the mystery before the game reveals it. Of course most importantly, they brought the item chest back. I only serves to hold extra fire arms in this game but having inventory management in a RE game after such a long time, was a nice surprise.

For the newer fans: All the great things about Resident Evil 4's controls are still there, ammo isn't limited enough that you can't go on a small shooting spree on normal or lower difficulty, and action sequences are sprinkled through the entire game. So if you like the action side more of the franchise, you can have fun with Revelations with the understanding it's not 4 or 5 in terms of shooting everything that comes at you.

To wrap this up, this is a great game compared to the junk Capcom has released in the RE franchise these couple of years. Good story, exploration, running from enemies, good narrative, and interesting enemy designs(though they get repetitive after a while.) I hope Capcom lets the team behind this game continue to do their own thing of bringing back the series closer to its original form because fans will response to that with purchases. Meanwhile, Capcom can use the main series to continue to try and force a square peg in a round hole with their No
recommended: it's not a rip-off of Call of Duty. It's action survival
hoursPlayed: trust us." With the magic that was Resident Evil 6
voteText: I'm sure that's working beautifully for them.\n"

reviewText:
This is a very fun game, but I would recommend you wait for it to come on sale for 25 dollars or less.

The game plays a lot like resident evil 4 and 5 with the over the shoulder view.  The controls are really good, and they aren't like the action controls for RE6.  The menu's had a little bit of trouble.  It's kind of weird how you select the weapons and eveything is blue so it can be hard to select a gun quickly.  They work, but I would prefer the type of menu from RE4 or even 5 over this one.

The story is over the top and fun just like most RE games.  There's a conspiricy theory, and a bunch of destruction and blood, so if you've played the other resident evil games this is more of the same.  One thing I really like about the story is the setting.  The majority of the game takes place on an old abandoned cruise ship.  The location reminds me of the mantion from resident evil 1 and is very creepy.  Even though the game isn't super scary, it is a lot more scary than the newer ones.  I would rank the scares in this game somewhere between resident evil 4 and 5.

The game ran really well for me and does not have super high system requirements.  I did have trouble getting the game to run in 1366 × 768 resolution for some reason.  I don't knonw if that has been changed yet, but I found it odd that I couldn't get the game to run in the resolution I wanted.  I ended up playing the game with a black border around my screen which was annoying.  I'm sure I could have messed around with it or found some sort of fix, but I wasn't really in the mood to do that when I played the game.  So just know you might have to look for a fix online if you want certain resolutions.

All in all I would recommend this game.  It is a turn back to the older games and even though it isn't that scary, it offers a couple scares for horror fans like me.  I would recommend you get this game if you really liked RE4 or even RE1 because of the setting.  They are releasing a sequel soon, and I hope that they build on this success to make a classic RE experience.

reviewText: Capcom returns to its roots somewhat with its latest offering, Resident Evil Revelations. Though the game still feels somewhat like a shooter, as opposed to a survival horror game, it captures a good bit of the feel of the original Resident Evil games, and while ammunition is plentiful, enemies take a significant number of rounds to take down, giving it more of a sense of desperation as ammunition supplies drain rather quickly. Overall, a fun enough game. 7/10.

reviewText:
Very disappointing...

My last RE game was with RE5 on PS3 (RE6 didn't appear impressive from the trailers I previewed and later from the player base review).

Then I read Revelation is considered better than RE6 - boy did I not understand how low the bar was set.

1. Gameplay: 7/10
RE4 set the de facto standard with over-the-shoulder" 3rd person action and I have no problems with it.
I used the keyboard and mouse setup - whole reason why I bought the PC version.
Camera can be a bit wonky at times but for 97-99% of the time I had no problems.
Difficulty wise
date: definitely harder than RE4 and RE5 (from what I remembered on Gamecube and PS3 anyway); Boss fights are challenging enough to require expending nearly all your ammunitions and proper aiming (no EZ rocket for you! RE4 boss fights haha...).\nAlso
recommended: no weapon can become "overpowered" in the sense they can't be upgraded beyond what the weapon mods allow for.\nFrom what I can tell

the DLC weapons offer no significant advantage over what is available in the stock game.

OK

I don't expect an Epic.

*New* Raid mode: 7/10
The RNG loot mode. I suppose its a decent grinder; 5-20 minutes on each stage (around 30 total) looking for random loots with map levels based on the campaign.

reviewText:
I know as of when I wrote this review I only have 0.1 hours in the game but I have played through this game 2 times on my 3DS already and messed around with the HD port on Wii U at a friend's house a little bit.This is the only Resident Evil game I have played so I have nothing to compair it to.

Story
I enjoyed the story it had a nice twist about half way through that really surprised me. The game being slip up into chapters seemed to fit really well which I usually hate when games do that. As far as character devlopment goes it never really explain who was who and kind of expected you to have played the other games.

Gameplay
The game play really felt like a pretty standard shooter, but I still enjoyed playing it. This game honestly wasn't all that scary though it was more in the gore of the monster you found then jump scares and stuff like that. The map was extremely confusing and not all that helpful leaving me to wander around quite a bit.

Co-op
I really enjoyed the co-op you basically play trough small parts of the story with a friend who controls the character that is usually controled by AI. However when playing on the 3DS and Wii U no one was ever online and I have heard from friends that it is hard to find people on PC as well. So if you can find a friend who also owns the game your in for a good time.

reviewText:
Great zombie killing 3rd person shooter with horror elements. Nice environments, though they may get repetitive if you plan to replay a lot. Some scenes are not advised for people under the age limit. Great character design and shapes, especially on Jill and Rachel, and particular bosses.

A lot of weapons and customization, character and weapon unlockables. Story is poor, like any other zombie game, there's outbreak, infection, bla-bla, we have to kill stuff and save earth. But what's important is the killing of things that are dead, because you don't really kill anything, because they are dead.

In this one you will mostly be on your own, in single player that is, usually you and your partner will be separated and occasionally meet up. In co-op mode however you play stages from selection of single player levels together with your friend, to clear the stage and not die. It's fun and may get boring after a while, like any repeatable thing, unless it's sex... well if you do 10-20 sexruns each day, you might get exhausted and also bored eventually. But don't get your hopes up that high, because there's rarely anyone that does that. Enjoy.

reviewText:
The best Resident Evil addition I've palyed in a while, with a good story, combat, and fimilar characters have made this game a generally fan favorite. However, the lack of CO-OP campaign as promised before release was a huge disappointment having your 2nd partner being simply and useless NPC that literally does no damage or anything beyond, just following you.

Also with this game comes the fimilar Raid Mode, though fun for hours eventually you will reach max level. At this point the Raid Mode takes a terrible dive in the fact at max level there are only 2-3 maps worth playing for any kind of progrerssion upgrades. This leads to a boring grind fest, doing the same waves, of the same spawn, in the same rooms, over and over.

Due to the new flavor the game as offered over Raccoon City and RE6 I'd give this game a 7/10 and is worth playing.

reviewText:
Well I really want to say this game is great, I like the monster designs, the game has extremely intense, creepy and difficult moments. But lord does this game drag out the story, It's like at some point the developers were punishing the consumer for buying the game by keeping the story running past the point of interest.

Raid mode, is well raid mode, not a bad experience and is enjoyable, which of course is made better when playing with a friend.

The game controls are awkward and stiff and what you would expect in a Resident Evil game (I came from Resident Evil 6 to this so I was a bit disappointed in character movement).

However, in comparison to many other AAA titles with an extremely large price tag (that never drops) and questionable season pass you do get what you pay for in Resident Evil Revelations.

reviewText:
Quick Summary: Third person action shooter very similar to Resident Evil 5, but at times noticeably lower graphics and some actual downgrades in gameplay mechanics. This is likely due to the fact that Revelations is a port of a Nintendo hand held game, later upgraded with HD graphics, and was never meant to be the next “great” Resident Evil game. Still, it’s fun and time consuming so you’ll get your money’s worth even if you didn’t buy the various DLCs.

Despite the fact that Revelations was released a few years after Resident Evil 5, the story of Revelations actually takes place earlier, as a kind of prequel (though unrelated plot-wise). You play BSAA agent Jill Valentine for the most part, but in each chapter you’ll regularly control different people such as Chris Redfield or other BSAA agents.  You know Jill is the main character though since she’s the only one who can mod her weapons with upgrade kits, and swap guns at the various loadout crates scattered around the area. Jill and her partner Parker are on a mission exploring an abandoned cruise ship related to terrorist activity from years before. As usual in Resident Evil games, “terrorist” means bio-weapons that create monsters to be unleashed on the world. This time around the weapon in question is the T-Abyss virus, that doesn’t make traditional zombies, but instead makes “oozes” which look kind of like humanoid tubeworms with claws and spiky teeth. Of course, that’s just the weak stuff. There are a bunch of giant bosses and super creepy monsters wandering the cruise ship as well.

If you’ve played Resident Evil 5, the gameplay should be very familiar to you, except that now you can just press the mouse button for a quick jab attack. Just like in RE 5 though, regular melee isn’t much use except for breaking boxes in the campaign (it’s more useful in Raid mode). You still have special contextual power hits that do a lot of damage to stunned enemies, but it’s a lot harder to set up stuns in Revelations. To kill most enemies you’ll have to rely on your guns. Various guns are found throughout the game (you can’t buy them in campaign) and they can only be upgraded with weapon “parts” that you find lying around. For example, your basic pistol may have 3 upgrade slots so you can add up to 3 weapon upgrades like + damage, faster shooting, and larger magazine, and swap for better ones that you find later. There’s no “money” used in the campaign for buying upgrades. Also note that even though you are usually with a partner throughout the campaign, this is not a co-op game. You cannot go through the story with a friend.

Another new feature for Revelations is the Genesis device, which is just a scanner despite its fancy name. You can quickly switch to the scanner at almost any time to scan enemies (alive or dead) and it adds a % to your “data.” For example scanning an ooze could give you 10% and scanning a tougher enemy might give you 20%. Every time you reach 100%, you get a healing herb added to your inventory, and the % resets to 0. It’s a slow but steady way to gain herbs at various points in the game. The Genesis can also be used to locate hidden items (like ammo or herbs) lying invisible on the ground.

Pros:
+A spooky Resident Evil game with enemies more gruesome than zombies, and no “human” enemies so you don’t need to hide from enemy gunfire (though there are some ranged oozes). There is a lot of backtracking in this game, and you’re going to go through most areas of the cruise ship several times. This means you have opportunities to pick up things that you missed the previous times through.
+The story is compelling, but it’s episodic which means every chapter starts with a “previously on Resident Evil Revelations” cutscene to catch you up in case you didn’t buy every episode.
+The Raid mode is the highlight of the game and allows you and a partner to level up by playing through areas from the game’s campaign. You also acquire BP (kind of like money) that you can use to buy weapons and weapon upgrade parts. You’ll need to get new gear when you level up because weapons have fixed levels. For example you start at level 1 with a level 1 gun, but when you’ve advanced, you may want to buy a level 2 gun, etc.

Cons:
-Since this is a mobile game port, the graphics and handling isn’t quite up to snuff compared to Resident Evil 5 or 6. There’s some frame rate stuttering on my computer (which ran RE 5 smoothly), and like Resident Evil 6, every time you start the game there are half a dozen little load screens to wait through.
-The game’s co-op Raid mode doesn’t have that many people playing anymore apparently. This may be because you can’t “drop in” to someone’s game. The host has to set up a game and wait for people to join, sometimes for a long time if nobody is searching for a match that very second. Most people probably don’t have the patience for that. This means if you want to play co-op, you need to set it up with a friend beforehand. Also, like RE 5, there’s no text or voice chat in the co-op.

Overall, the game is a fun continuation of the action shooter style of Resident Evil games, and the creepy deserted cruise ship has a nice atmosphere for horror. Raid mode will occupy a lot of your time after you’ve finished the story. Once you’ve mastered Raid mode’s Abyss tier of levels, the campaign’s Infernal difficulty (hard mode) will seem like a walk in the park.

reviewText:
As a huge fan of RE4 and even RE5, I really enjoyed this 3DS port. What I enjoyed of the previous games was the over the shoulder camera and having to watch your ammo while you fight monsters. There are many differences of course, good but not necessarily better, though certainly not worse.

GENERAL INFO
If you've played RE4/5 you'll know generally what to expect here, if not check out screenshots and videos for this game. The vast majority of the game takes place on a large cruise ship. During the course of the game you will explore it and find keys that unlock more of the ship to progress the story. Every once in a while the game will switch to a different duo and play as them for a little while with preset weapons. Not my favorite parts but they do help break up the monotony of the ship and explain more of the story.

GUNS
Where the game shines are the weapons and upgrades. You can have any 3 weapons equipped, even 3 pistols if you wanted though that's stupid. There are pistols, shotguns, smgs/assault rifles, long range rifles, and magnums. For each weapon type there are different guns you will find with differing stats. When you find a gun and take it back to your storage box thing you will have it forever (the gun you dropped is returned too). This is how you switch out your guns and change their upgrades, you can't do it anywhere for obvious balance reasons. Upgrading guns is a lot of fun. Each gun has anywhere from 1 to 5 slots for upgrades, and you can apply upgrades and take them off at will. Upgrades include the standard fare of higher damage, higher bullet capacity, faster reload, etc. and many more unique ones.

YOUR AI PARTNER
By far the biggest advantage this game has, especially over RE5, is that although you have an AI partner he can safely be ignored. In RE5 even if you were playing solo, you still had to manage your AI partners inventory and keep them alive, but thankfully they were generally fairly smart though still a hassle. Here your AI partner is invincible, the enemies pretty much always push past him to come after you, and while your partner can shoot they rarely seem to. Are they useless? Yes. Do they stay out of your way and present no hassle for you and let you enjoy the single player experience you want? Thank goodness yes! Of course you can play co-op if you wanted, but it's far from forced.

PLAYTHROUGH INFO
Your first playthrough on normal if you are reasonably thorough and don't try to rush it will take you about 8-10 hours. Like in RE4 there is a new game+ mode where you keep all your weapons and ammo from before and start over. That's already fun, but this game has an infernal difficulty which you can, and are probably expected to, play on a new game+. This mode features a lot more enemies, enemies in different places than normal, and even enemies early on you wouldn't normally see until later in the game. Furthermore, items are in different places and nothing at all like on normal. Infernal mode is practically a whole new game!

RAID MODE
As if all this wasn't awesome enough there's this RPG-progression-like mode called Raid Mode. In it you do a quick mission where your goal is to find the exit. There are many of these missions, and as you do them you gain experience which allows you to level up. The higher level missions will let you find higher level weapons, of which you need to be the appropriate level to wield. The weapons will have increased stats and effects, very similar to Borderlands random gun drops. You can prepare for each mission using what you've earned/bought. Yes there is a store which resets every time you enter it. You can easily spend dozens of hours on this mode alone. This mode can also be played in co-op if you wish.

CONCLUSION
If you liked RE4/5 definitely check this game out, you aren't likely to be disappointed. If you've never played them before take a look at some lets plays for a good idea.
P.S. Review was 1700 chars too long, had to shorten >.<.

reviewText: It's a game designed for handhelds ported to console/PC later, the graphics in game are crap, the cutscenes actually look WORSE than anything in game despite them being prerendered, the story is played out like a 90s horror/mystery flick and the choice of removing the laser sight is one of the most questionable things this series has done in a long list of complaints. And yet I can't help but enjoy this game. It's a fantastic return to the horror roots of the series. The raid mode is somewhat decent and can be pretty enjoyable with friends. And the game is actually really well paced. It doesn't touch RE4 (which IMO has had the perfect gameplay pacing I've ever seen) but it's definetly the best game to come out in a while. This game remembers an olden time where you didn't have a co-op partner with you for the entire game. And it recalls the days when you actually had to aim and be careful with ammo. The upgrades you find while playing are incredibley helpful and well worth looking for (♥♥♥♥ RE6's perks). I don't quite have enough room to go on about all the right things this game did, but it's easily one of the best releases in the franchise. There are a few parts that even scared me, which is more than I can say for RE5/6. I bought this game on the 3ds and enjoyed it enough to swap it towards the PC release. This is the best Steam Resident Evil game for sure. The controls are a bit off with KB+M but it's tolerable. I'd say the game is good enough to be above being looked over for bad porting.  8.8/10.

reviewText:
Resident Evil Revelations (from here forward known as Resilations) is a pretty solid Resident Evil game, not amazing or revolutionary, but it's enough to get your survival horror mojo going if you're a fan of the series. If you've never played a Resident Evil I recommend the HD remake of the original to Resilations.

As a Resident Evil game it fits somewhere in between Code Veronica and RE4 in terms of the horror/action/hilariously convoluted storytelling ratio. It does a good job of making itself feel like it's more challenging and is putting you in more danger than it really is and the Queen Zenobia is a pretty good location to set the game in. The early moments where the game lets the atmospheric groan of the empty ship surround you as the screen shifts every so slightly to the rhythm of the ocean are the most unnerving parts of the game. Eventually it becomes obvious that ammo and health is pretty plentiful and you're feel too well equipped by the end of the game for it to be scary or even more than a little tense.

It's pretty obvious that this is a port from the 3DS. While very impressive on that piece of hardware even an HD facelife doesn't keep it from looking dated, even the cutscenes have a stange grainy/poorly compressed look to them. It's also still apparent that it was meant to be played in small chunks. The game is split into little episodes that usually run roughly 45 minutes and end on a big cliff hanger (which usually resolves in the silliest way possible) it was obviously designed around playing on a commute or lunch hour. It even plays a little last time on Resilations" recap before each episode like it's assuming you're not going to play the game for long periods. Playing it sporadically probably helped hide some of the games issues with backtracking. At one point you escape a flooded area and the the next episode you just dive back in and swim though it all over again.

The best parts of the game revolve around Jill Valentine investigating the Queen Zenobia
date: but you're constantly being pulled from that storyline the plotlines of other characters and when you're back to Jill you end up backtracking a decent amount meaning that
hoursPlayed: you just don't get enough of the best parts. Tht being said Resilations is overall a solid games and is still a good game even when you're not in the Jill Valentine segments. The RE4 style mechanincs for fighting are fun even if Resilations doesn't have that game's excellent level design to play around with it in. Raid mode adds some life to the short campaign although your milage may vary with it."

reviewText:
Jill Sandwich returns in the best Resident Evil title in years.
This DS port surpasses both the lacklustre RE5 and the wankfest RE6, and whilst the levels are not too ambitious, this title has far better pacing than any RE game since 4. The new limited ammo and new upgrade system help stop the game from becoming the gunfest of the previous titles, but what I felt hurt the game was the removal of the context sensitive melee attacks for head and knee shots, which in previous titles made combat feel far more fluid. Instead, Revelations arms the player with a one-button knife attack, which allows for some cheap kills.
The excellent new Raid mode is the replacement to previous title's Mercenary mode. Gone is the time limit that crippled the previous version; instead we get to maintain a constant inventory and level up. It feels like everything The Mercenaries always should have been.

The Real Resident Evil 6 out of Ten

reviewText:
This is the game fans that loved the games before Resident Evil 4 were waiting for. It has the horror aspecs, it has the asmosphere, it has the creepy soundtrack. It really does feel like survival horror until about the last couple of chapters in the game.
Pros:
- Good gameplay
- Scary and creative enemies
- Epic and disturbing boss battles
- Chris Redfield is back!
- Jill Valentine is back with a skin-tight suit ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)
- More skin tight suits
- Homage to old-school survival horror
- Interesting setting, exploration is encouraged
- Beautiful environments and graphics
- Good difficulty, especially on higher diff. settings
- Rage mode is good fun
- Minimal loading screens
- High replayability

Cons:
- Facial animations are a bit wonky (not a big deal)
- A bit short (again, not a big deal because replayability is high)
- Keith and Quint are the most annoying friggin' characters yet! I thought Ashley Graham was a bit annoying but not at all compared to these doofuses!
- Holds your hand a bit too much later in the game as you stockpile ammo easily by this time
- No Jill Sandwiches ( ͠° ͟ʖ ͡°)

reviewText:
This biohazard is more of a throwback to the first game. One main location that it takes place in with some minor cuts into other scenes to add to the main plot. Nicely done Capcom, too bad this was only released for 3DS and pc.

The mouse controls are amazing, no longer does it feel sluggish and clunky like it did in the previous PC Biohazard releases. The issues that people have with stuttering on the doors is due to the game loading the area map, all you're doing is waiting in a room anyway; I'd rather have it stutter there loading rather than have the game stuttering w/ texture popins as I'm walking around a corner.

The story for the game takes place between Bio 4 and Bio 5, it depects how the BSAA was formed and introduces a lot of new characters to the Biohazard mix.

reviewText:
Revelations is a welcome addition to the Resident Evil franchise. It attempts to go back to its survival horror roots with a tense atmosphere and semi-tank controls. Revelations does not disappoint in that aspect as there are several moments where you do not expect what will be around the corner waiting for you. It really is no secret that Capcom wants to take the franchise into the action/third-person style; and Revelations still has aspects of this as well. It may not be as bad as other Resident Evil games but the game is still quite enjoyable. With the introduction of Revelations comes the Genesis, a device used to show hidden items through-out the environment.

The Genesis adds an interesting layer to the gameplay. The main purpose of the Genesis is to gain additional ammo and herbs. Of course you can also use the Genesis to scan B.O.W.s., whether alive or dead, to gain more herbs with every 100% completion. There are very few healing items in the open world so it is highly advised you use the Genesis as much as possible. Overall the Genesis is an interesting addition to a Resident Evil game but in the end it shows that the game really was made with a handheld in mind.

A few gripes with the game is that the story telling isn’t the best. You are constantly switching back and forth between several people and this tends to mud up the flow of the timeline within the game. Another annoyance is the lack of healing items. There will be quite a few times you run out of them, as you can only carry five, and you only gain a small percentage from scanning monsters. The game also tends to hold your hand when you die, basically telling you what you did wrong and how to overcome it. I wish Capcom didn’t do and let the player figure it out like the past games.

In conclusion Revelations is a must have for any fans of the classic Resident Evil series. It takes a step back to recreate the tense setting and tries to instill fear into the player like the games of old with a few new twists on the gameplay.

Overall I give the game a 7 out of 10.

reviewText:
First off, only get this if it is $20 or less. Now, let's dig into the game:

It's pretty much a 'classic' resident evil when you play as Jill with all the improvements of aiming and moving. I must clarify AS JILL because when you play as any other character the game is garbage. Seriously. In Resident Evil 4 and previous games, you spent a lot of time wandering around, collecting keys, and solving puzzles. All of that only happens as Jill while playing as other characters is basically go there, shoot that, and get bored from the truely horrifying bad story.

Let's put more emphasis on the fact that the story is the only scary thing about this game. It's bad. Very bad. How bad? It has 'Revelations' as a tagline which suggests a twist in the story! This twist is predictable and EVERY SINGLE CHARACTER acts they are from a senior high drama class. I would say something about them being on drugs, but drugs would have improved the story, dialog, and characters.

It took me about 5 hours to beat this game, and only 3~3.5 of it was with Jill. I didn't try Raid mode because who gives a ♥♥♥♥.
