reviewText:
Now that I unlocked all achievements I can finally put the game aside and never play it again in the near future. The only reason might be to S rank the remaining campaign chapters I haven’t done yet or to unlock even more achievments in the free online portal found on residentevil.net. So here we begin this in two sections separated review. First we sink into the campaign mode before we head on to the action packed Raid Mode.

Campaign
People will tell you that Revelations was the first step of Capcom to bring the series back to its survival horror roots but I can’t completely agree with that. The campaign is split into 12 chapters. The majority of chapters take place on a cruise ship while others are more of the typical action shooter the series is known for today with various changing locations and time periods. The cruise ship chapters feature narrow corridors, somewhat creepy atmosphere and are surprising the best chapters of the game while the action oriented chapters are mediocre at best compared to other action shooter games out there.

The storyline is one gigantic puzzle jumping back & forth between events and can be very confusing the first time around. But it’s not as convoluted as they say. It’s easy to differentiate who are the bad guys & good guys in this soap opera. To put the pieces together can be a very entertaining & is a motivator to continue playing until the end.

You run around mostly solo and if a partner is on your toes then it’s only an AI controlled partner. Unlike other entries the AI partner in Revelations doesn’t need to be instructed because he/she is basically invincible, got infinite ammo and shoots or doges when the need to shoot or dodge is required. The player is the true source of power in the roughly 11hour campaign here. He/she is is the one to deal the damage & the one that needs to heal himself.

Gameplay mechanics are very simple. This is after all a 3DS game ported & remastered for PC. Healing, throwing grenades, using the knife are bound to only a button and can be executed quick without much time of preparation which is a good thing compared to the clunky, overloaded mechanics used in other entries of the series. The only game mechanic that is poorly implemented is the Dodging-System. You basically have to push the action button & the analog stick short before an enemy hits you. But this button is bound to other actions like opening doors, shooting with the gun & picking up items and doesn’t work most of the time and requires lots of practice to be used to its fully extend.

Raid Mode

First introduced in Revelations 1 is the so called Raid Mode. This mode spawns three difficulties with 20 stages that must be unlocked as you play along. Raid is basically an Arcade Shooter in which you will be throw in all the locations of campaign mode and to solve tasks like killing all enemies or reaching the goal. Enemy spawns are fixed so they can be learned easily. You either play it alone or you invite one of your Steam Friends or search for strangers to play it in Co-Op.

After each stage you will be rated on accuracy, enemies routed & damage taken and earns you XP that level up your characters. Perfect players will be awarded with bonuses for no damage taken, elimination of all enemies and completing a stage at the recommended level. This results in higher currency which then can be used to buy new weapons and weapon upgrades in the in game shop.

Leveling up will raise the level of all characters. Characters are mere avatars with different skill sets. Some are good with SMGs, while others are better in using Shotguns, to take less damage or to dodge easier.

The only negative I have to write about Raid Mode is the lack of stages & the sheer amount of time investment to reach a new player level. Leveling up is so freaking slow that you replay some stages 10 or more times before you are able to survive in the next. Playing stages below recommented level & with an online partner is the key for faster level up, but it is a tedious process that gets you bored very quickly.

Conclusion

Revelations 1 is a fun little action shooter with horror elements that got so much to offer that you will be entertained for hours. Fans of the series should buy it without giving it a second thought. Achievement Hunters as well as casual gamers should think twice before they hit the purchase button, unless they are willing to spend time on the good but not perfect Raid Mode.

reviewText:
Not bad. It's not as scary as dead space or resident evil 2 but it makes up for it with great gameplay mechanics. It's an incredibly well done console port - both movement and mouse aiming are tight and responsive.

My only complaints are that the coop mode isn't fully integrated (no campaign coop mode), it's a separate arcade style series of missions. Disappointing because you have an AI partner with you for a large portion of the campaign, woulndn't have been difficult to implement. I don't care much for the approach capcom took in trying to develop the story with this game. It basically creates a bunch of 'episode' segments, the majority of them you play as Jill but some of them toss you into alternate character side missions that really don't contribute much to the game.

Also, the game is a little too easy. Even playing on infernal mode with a brand new game I didn't have to worry about ammo management after 2 or 3 chapters (Although the first chapter is pretty tricky). If you have good aim this won't be terribly challenging for you.

TL;DR  - Pros: Great gameplay and controls; Jill has a nice ♥♥♥
Cons: No campaign coop mode; Too many side character missions; Kinda easy on max difficulty

reviewText: A pretty decent game in the Resident Evil franchise that is a breath of fresh air from the stink of number 6.\nYou play as various characters as they investigate a mysterious organisation known as Veltro which is linked to the destruction of a floating" city and it's destruction under a new virus
date:
the T-Abyss.

PRO
- Interesting story
- Colourful characters
- Links as a prequel to 5 nicely
- Good graphics for a 3DS port
- Controls are good and responsive
- Enemies are varied
- Lots of unlocks and achievements
- Added raid mode is fun (Better than mercenaries IMO)

CON
- Partners seem pretty useless as enemies NEVER attack them and ALWAYS go for you
- Comic relief characters seem very out of place
- Search tool sometimes feels annoying
- Can be attacked off screen a few times

All in all
recommended: a decent game and now I believe in my top favourites of this series.\n7/10"

reviewText:
I've played this game for a little over an hour. I couldn't stand to play it for any longer. I watched DansGaming play it a bit during his Halloween Horror Game Marathon.
____

I had a choice. Spend my funds on RE4 or on RE Revelations. For the sake of going with something new, I chose the latter and now I deeply regret my decision. I should have done a bit more research. Like another reviewer pointed out, RE Revelations plays like a boring and stripped down version of RE4. And it adds a new, super annoying feature whose purpose I do not understand. A bioscanner. After you kill monsters you can scan their bodies and if you scan enough of their bodies you get some sort of bonus (I think it was a life bonus or something like that). That doesn't sound too bad, does it? Well, it's not bad. The part that infuriates me is that you need the scanner to find ALL ITEMS. Walk into a room, it's empty. Wait, use your bioscanner scanner to look around the room, and aha! There's that apparently organic ammo you needed. Or that keycard you need to open that door. What an absolutley silly, timewasting, and nonsensical feature.

Unfortunately, this game has bigger problems than just a silly loot finding system. The graphics are bad, the atmosphere is mediocre, the characters and dialogue are terribly written, and the combat is unrefined, depthless, and above-all, boring.  I don't understand the positive reviews for the game. If I could return this game, I would in a heartbeat.

reviewText: Resident Evil Revelations is kind of Capcoms apology about Resident Evil 5 & 6 being more about shooting zombies and less about horror gameplay, and it tries to be a bit like Resident Evil 4, but fails at it.\nResident Evil Revelations's greatest shortcoming is that it's mostly just boring and average. The story is boring, the characters are boring, the gameplay is boring, the graphics are average. When this game originally released on the 3DS it looked very impressive on the small screen, but now it's not so impressive on a 1080p screen.\nIf you are desperate for a horror game to play, RE Revelations is probably better than 90% of the indie horror games that are currently flooding Steam, but that isn't saying much.

reviewText: A pretty decent game in the Resident Evil franchise that is a breath of fresh air from the stink of number 6.\nYou play as various characters as they investigate a mysterious organisation known as Veltro which is linked to the destruction of a floating" city and it's destruction under a new virus
date:
the T-Abyss.

PRO
- Interesting story
- Colourful characters
- Links as a prequel to 5 nicely
- Good graphics for a 3DS port
- Controls are good and responsive
- Enemies are varied
- Lots of unlocks and achievements
- Added raid mode is fun (Better than mercenaries IMO)

CON
- Partners seem pretty useless as enemies NEVER attack them and ALWAYS go for you
- Comic relief characters seem very out of place
- Search tool sometimes feels annoying
- Can be attacked off screen a few times

All in all
recommended: a decent game and now I believe in my top favourites of this series.\n7/10"

reviewText:
This is a game about a loser guy named Cristopher trying to find his wife, but then it turns out she's actually on a boat full of monsters. Ring any ♥♥♥♥ing bells yet? It should, because that exact same thing was done years ago, and it was called Silent Hill 2 and was actually good. Too bad Crapcom can't make good games without ripping off people who know what they're doing. Anyway, Cris gets a letter from Jane Valentine (Is she supposed to be related to Vincent Valentine from Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children? Get REAL, Crapcock.) and has to find her on a boat. But he can't ♥♥♥♥ing find her. How hard is it to find a boat, Cris? IT'S AN OCEAN. THERE IS LITERALLY NOTHING IN IT BUT BOATS. So you have to play as Jane, and you have to spend all your ♥♥♥♥ing time looking at people with your Fisher Price Monster Scanner kit, to figure out if they're monsters or not. Meanwhile Cris is suddenly on a ♥♥♥♥ing MOUNTAIN? What. There are no ♥♥♥♥ing boats on a mountain, you prick. Crap♥♥♥♥ is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ developer who can not even REMEMBER what it happening IN THEIR OWN GAMES. It just gets worse from there. Really, it would be a lot better if this wasn't such a HUGE Silent Hill ripoff, except set on a boat. And don't even get me started on the Raid Mode, which is pretty much all the worst elements from World of Warcraft, slapped into a half-baked ♥♥♥♥♥♥ grind marathon.

SCORES:
Graphics: 6/10. This used to be a Game Boy Advance game, and you can tell. However, one chick gets horribly and painfully turned into a terrible monster and begs you to kill her, except she has her ♥♥♥♥ out the entire time, and it's pretty clear that the devs were literally masturbating while designing their ♥♥♥♥♥ Zombie. So it gets points for zombie ♥♥♥♥.
Music: 3/10. The game does not have music.
Gameplay: 7/10. You point the Scan Man 3000 at a zombie, and a little bar fills up and you get a herb. Then I guess you smoke that herb or something. Since the game is 420 friendly it gets bonus points.
Story: 5/10. Again, Silent Hill did it better.

FINAL SCORE: B-

YOU MIGHT ENJOY THIS GAME IF...
You get crazy boners from bloody zombie ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Is it the perfect Resident Evil game?
No.
But is it a fun Resident Evil game...?
Heck yeah, and here's why:

Nice story, good atmosphere, fluid action, a good voice cast, and Raid mode (go through the different stages and shoot through different difficulties of enemies, unlocking weapons, parts, etc through beating them). Though, of course, this game isn't without problems:

The graphics are ok at best, though that's likely because it was originally on the 3DS. Also, while certain new characters like Parker and Raymond are great, others like Jessica, Quint, and Keith are... not so much. Playing the game on Normal, ammo is abundant, so a harder difficulty is recommended if you want to feel more of an actual challenge.  Lastly, the final boss is about 50/50 when it comes to enjoyability. To me, it was frustrating until I figured out its pattern, which didn't take too long.

Overall, not my favorite Resident Evil, but still an enjoyable one for sure. If you get it discounted (or in my case, gifted), it's well worth your time.

reviewText: I am not sure if me and the other reviewers have played the same game. I have to say that I was incredibly dissapointed in it (though I suppose no more than in say, RE6), and I honestly cannot recommend this game to anyone, not even fans of the franchise. I know this is a port from a handheld, so I suppose there is no point in complaining about graphics, however, the game is really really short (the entire campaign takes under 6 hours), you are being thrown from character to character, from location to location and it is disorienting, makes it difficult to manage your items or anticipate what you might need, and some of the characters you have to control are absolutely atrociously written. Speaking of writing, it is rather convoluted, even for a Resident Evil game. The fact that you will play through flashback sequences presented without much rhyme or reason is not helping. The voice - acting is almost as bad as RE 1 times, but this time there is no excuse of being a pioneering game. Overall it is tedious, often boring, unrewarding awful game with clunky controls. Do yourself a favour and buy the RE 1 HD Remaster or RE 4 HD instead.\n\nBonus: There are two characters supposedly provided as comic relief that boils down to saying THIS BLOWS". All. The. Time."

reviewText: Don't let the hours on this game fool you, I've played it before (this was gifted to me). Trying to give this another go after failing to peak my interest the first time, I couldn't do it. I have problems sleeping, unless I play this game. This game is so mind numbingly boring that it makes me sleepy. Running from room to room gunning down the same types of monsters gets obviously repetitive and the game has absolutely no scare factor. I've played every single Resident Evil game I can think of, and I even like the terrible first person Resident Evil more than this back in the day of the first Playstation. The only thing horrific about this game is that it is an abomination to the Resident Evil classic feel. Those that claim it has that feeling must be delusional, or they don't remember the older games. I've played it on the hardest difficulty and rarely ran out of ammo, there was absolutely nothing that made me jump or think Oh man

reviewText:
This game is a mobile game turned PC/ console without any major changes to it whatsoever.
The gameplay is the same, so for a PC, it is extemely limited. You'd have a hard time squeezing more than 30 hours out of this title for what little there is to do in the game.
The sheer quality of the game is lackluster at best. They didn't add or improve any textures at all to fit a larger screen than a 3DS. The enemies and enviroment are bland in the best case scenario, and most of the enviroments are repeated in the game. It feels like a lot of pointless running around because of the lack of fresh content.
The story was pretty terrible if you never read the Divine Comedy, because you just have nothing to relate to the plot's only allusion. The story lacks any form of symbolism, and frankly the character line up is worse than ever (ANY other title). It looks like they turned from even moderately paced action shooters like 4 or 5 and tried to tie the experience to a survival horror. The problem is that it lacks any of the puzzles that a survival horror should have, and without a story, it has nothing to offer the player motivation to complete the title.

reviewText:
I haven't played any of the game yet, aside from 10 minutes of the single player campaign. I am very dissapointed that there is no Co-Op Campaign mode as in Resident Evil 5. Btw, I beat and loved Resident Evil 4. The thing that makes me not recommend this game is the fact that on the Steam Store Page for RE:Revelations it states that is co-op. I, along with many other fans of the series, believe this to be very misleading. True, there is a Raid mode, but I want to experience an entire game's campaign with a good friend, and make awesome memories and have amazing experiences that we can laugh about for years to come.

Campcom seems to be going the way of SquareEnix, that is to say, money grubbing and misleading their fans al for a few (million) bucks.

Please Campcom, add a co-op campaign!

reviewText:
This is my first review, I have no idea how to write one, but I will try my best.

Here I go,

This game is NOTHING like resident evil should be, no zombies, no tentsion, no puzzles, this game is NOT resident evil, I don't know what it is, but I know what it isn't.
I would actually maybe still enjoy it because it has fantastic graphics, but I just cant get over of the poorly written story, the SCORE TABLE !!!! YEAH !!! SCORE TABLE !!! WTF ?!?! ... I mean ... I was looking for a game that I could play for the story, I was a fan of the original resident evil 1,2,3 and maybe even 4 because it had a compelling storyline and I get emerged into the world, the puzzles that needed to be solved to gert ahead where just the icing, then the best thing for me in the originals was the camera angles, it just added so much. For me, the first three games where perfect.
So to anyone reading this, I dont know if anyone agrees with me or not, but I would not recommend this, its something that will ruin your fond memories of the original.

reviewText:
This is the first Resident Evil game that I ever played, and it is in my opinion a great way to get familiar with the series.

I didn't know much about Resident Evil before playing this game. I had watched a couple of the movies, which were not great, but as is often the case the movies don't really have that much in common with the games. The movies can't compare to the games.

The story in this game revolves around Jill and her current partner Parker who are sent out to investigate a cruise ship after the corpses of some strange creatures appear along the shore. Things don't go as planned (as is often the case with these types of games), so Chris and his current partner Jessica are sent out to look for Jill and Parker.

The story is very episodic, and feels almost more like a tv-series than a game. You have the main episodes" focusing on Jill

reviewText:
The game has correctly scaled back to the idea of ammo conservation, claustraphopic atmospheres and suspense.

However,

It's shoddy music, cheap jump scares, beyond awful combat mechanics and insultingly easy fights and puzzles that are more irritating than tricky - make me concerned that this was made by an actual legit company. The only sign of actual effort in this is the generally large size of the game and its levels. Even though it is a cakewalk it will kill a good 10+ hours.

Oh yeah, and Jill is still hot. But youll soon forget that the second the horrific, stupid, pointless side characters turn up, with thier own mini missions and humourless jokes.

An irritating 5/10 even if you love the old Resi's

reviewText:
I don't usually write reviews, but this game... Jesus Christ!!This could be a good game, it's fun at starts, but then, the cheesy and awkward dialogue and stupid things that happen start to get to you! The creature design is just awful, you're either fighting giant plastic lizards that look like they just came out of a Power Rangers episode, or you're fighting 6 days old pieces of lasagna with legs, not to mention a giant meatball with tentacles!
The gameplay mechanics are standard Resident Evil style, but with some really annoying differences that are just enough to make you wanna throw your keyboard through the window!And the story, oh my god the story! You can spot the plot twists from a mile away, and there's two guys, Jackass(that's his name!!) and the other what's is face,that remind me of an idiot Snoop Dog and a Sex Offender on parole.
I wanted to like this game, i really did,and i was enjoying at first but then...
Oh, and the game drags and drags and drags until you think it should have ended a boss ago, then it drags a little bit more!
Do yourself a favour, go have a beer and stay away from this one!

reviewText:
Slow, boring, ugly and souless.  This feels like one of those half finished cheap early access games that have long been abandoned that always seem to be in bundles.

Resi 5 was decent, 6 was poor and this is beyond abysmal.  The graphics on the monsters looks like they are from 1997. The voice acting and cut scenes are terrible.  Truly the low point in the Resident Evil franchise (yes even below the movies).

reviewText:
TL;DRI don't give a ♥♥♥♥ if it's too long for you to read, if you are on Steam you surely have plenty of time to spare.

Resident Evil: RevelationsResident Evil Revelations? That 3DS game that was one of the first to have a demo so all the nine year olds could simultaneously ♥♥♥♥ themselves and ♥♥♥♥ their parents off for lying about their age? Ya, that one. It made it’s way on to PC, and I’m happy about that, because it made the Humble Monthly slightly less ♥♥♥♥ in a really contrived way, and is good. Keep in mind that the computer I used to beat the game has about as much processing power as a modded ZX Spectrum with a slightly better resolution, so that may have hindered the experience. And let’s just get the PC Master race ♥♥♥♥s out of here quick; it’s 60FPS, so you can go back to circle jerking to old Zero Punctuation episodes. Also, the only other Resident Evil I’ve played is Six, and Six is referring to it’s review score out of ten if you divide it by 3, so my hopes weren’t very high here, however wrong that assumption was.

General info about the gameYou play as, wait, scratch that, I’m pretty sure you play as almost every character at some point. But the missions sort of revolve around Jill and Parker for the majority of the game. Jill is otherwise known as Generic White Chick #1, with Kardashian levels of cleavage showing and almost no rounds for the only 9mm she brought on board. Parker is a kind of interesting European dude, who is super buff, but not so cookie-cutter I’d call him generic. Anyways, ♥♥♥♥ hits the metaphorical fan, stuff goes down, lalala. I won’t get into the story because it’s actually pretty good.

What is trash?First, we go over the trash portions of this game. The most obvious trash part is the god damned optimizations. I know I said I’m running a garbage computer, but somehow I manage to get 30FPS (PC Master Race: *heavy triggering*) in combat, and 5 FPS when walking into slightly different areas. The mere idea of anything below 60 is ♥♥♥♥ing ridiculous considering this game runs on the potato formally known as the 3DS. Other than that, boss fights are slower and more boring than pretending to be interested at a funeral for that one ♥♥♥♥-head uncle you have that you really don’t care about but have to play pretend for a couple hours. You literally pummel over 100 rounds into these blobs of flesh and they still have the audacity to attempt wipe their ♥♥♥ with you. RE’s idea of a boss fight is taking a normal enemy, finding the “Properties” tab, then increasing size, health, and damage. Then they litter the room with vents strangely all along the ground as if the place is made for umpa loompas or some ♥♥♥♥, then ♥♥♥♥ the screen with enemies. The thing RE doesn’t understand is that just making a ton of enemies then put a bounty on your head doesn’t make it horror. The less you see the enemy, the scarier it is, they aren’t our car pool buddies.

But now, now, I dedicate an entire paragraph to the final boss fight. If you don’t like spoilers, stick your head in a fishbowl then paint it black or something, because the spoiler train is docking at this station. First off, you are granted with this man who injects himself with a red virus I kind of assumed was Kool-Aid, then half expected the man to turn into the Kool-Aid man and run around yelling “OH YEAH” at me while breaking walls. Sadly, he just turns into a 7 foot baddie that can take more 12 gauges to the heart than an enraged chimpanzee on steroids. He then teleports his dumb ♥♥♥ right in front of you so you can ogle the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ model and how the graphics artist tried to cover that up with glares from light sources that don’t exist. He then shows his heart for approximately enough time to fire twice, three times if you’re ♥♥♥♥ing Clint Eastwood. You then repeat this about 30 times, or until you are out of health kits and waiting to die. This all happens while your partner stands off to the side pretending his downs is acting up so he doesn’t have to fight alongside you. The best part about this fight is that if you don’t hit the heart, the attack didn’t happen. You can throw a grenade at his feet, but no damage done. He doesn’t even flinch. But what’s even worse than all of that is the fact that I was playing on Easy because playing at anything above Easy requires more reaction time than 15 FPS can grant me. I couldn’t imagine what that would be like on hard. I’d have a tourniquet around my neck before I did that on insane.

What is good and alright?Other than that ballocks, the cutscenes are alright, weapons are cool, customization is pretty good, but now I get to rant about something else: the magnum. So about a third through the game you start picking up magnum rounds. Before that you would pick up shotgun shells, and then you get a shotgun shortly after. But here, you don’t get the magnum until about 80% through the game. So here I am, looking like a ♥♥♥♥ing 60 year old dementia patient looking around every corner for something that doesn’t exist for about half the game. Then I find the magnum, or Desert Eagle, but no copyright infringement so its some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ rip off name like “HaWk 7-l3n,”  you have about 20 rounds for the rest of the game. So that is roughly 10-15 kills with that. Not bad, now what if you run across a boss? “Well ♥♥♥♥ you,” Capcom says with the kind of grin 19th century English landlords had when their tenants gave them about 90% of their food as rent. So I basically gave my regular pistol all the dope upgrades, almost to the point where the other weapons looked like someone forgot about a unit in Civilization V for 300 years and now it’s carrying spears when everyone else has M16’s; effectively useless.

Steam says it took me 10 hours to beat the game, not a bad amount of time. I mean, that’s trash for anyone who paid $35 for it, but in my case I traded I think Rust for it, so that’s pretty good. However, Resident Evil says it took me 5 hours to complete it. Maybe this was result of  15 FPS, or maybe I spent like 5 hours idling or getting off to the wide array of graphics options for my slight PC Master Race side. Either way, I ♥♥♥♥ing hope raid mode makes up for that, even though I don’t know what it is. Throughout the campaign, it kept saying “unlocked strap-on ♥♥♥♥♥ #12 for raid mode” or different variations, but little did the game know that I give less ♥♥♥♥♥ about that than Christians’ opinions.

This game definitely earns the “Developer fap material” award, since there wasn’t a woman in the game that didn’t have either half her ♥♥♥♥ showing or generally missing pieces of clothes you’d think you’d want on a spec ops mission. One of the women are missing half of their pants. Like, it literally is just missing. There is one full leg, then one missing. This isn’t a ♥♥♥♥ing Victoria’s Secret fashion show. The girls are all hot, but then you got to wonder if they made a prerequisite for joining the armed forces “Has to be a model and have minimum of D-cup bra.” (Yes, I had to look that one up.)

ConclusionSo is the game good? Yes. Is it worth $35? If you are okay with games shorter than the lifespan of Chinese sweat shop workers, then yes, it’s worth it. And before you hit that “report” button, realize that I’m not racist, I hate everyone equally.

reviewText:
The game started pretty promising, it had that feel of vulnerability, that focus on exploration. But there is ONE thing that stopped me from playing.

Forget the crappy textures, the dumb story, the ridiculous enemies called B.O.Ws (they're more disturbing than scary), or the silly scanning system (at least in Metroid Prime we could actually read on the stuff we scan, here its just for getting health and finding invisible items). Nay, one thing, made me say NEVER AGAIN.

That boss. Holy ♥♥♥♥ that boss. Made me ♥♥♥♥ my pants man.

There's a reason why survival horror is so distinct from other shooters : you don't want to fight. If you fight, its because you got backed in a corner, that you have no other choice. You use precious resources that you need to manage. You avoid areas with many monsters and use stealth to survive. Sometimes, like in Amnesia : the Dark Descent, you have no weapon at all and must avoid monsters at all costs.

Not this game. This game broke my suspension of disbelief so hard I laughed. Don't be fooled, its a silly 3rd person action shooter just like the other modern" Resident Evils.

What happened is this : you arrive in this area. Theres a few monsters
date: so I pick them off with my pistol. Its a shopping mall. I secure the area (since you can't stealth)
hoursPlayed: lift open a gate. I hear this weird voice. "Mayday
voteText: mayday
helpfulPercent: help us (...)". Its the comms officer I'm supposed to go find for the key to the communications room. Then i see something wrong : a door is being banged on and shaked and theres a lock on it. Let me ask you : what would any sane person do? Especially in a survival situation? You'd probably GTFO OF THERE RIGHT?\n\nBut no
votesHelpful: you're expected to shoot the lock and release teh creature within. Cuz you need the key. Nevermind that you could pick the lock
votesTotal: or smash the door down. No
votesFunny: its much easier to fight A FRIGGIN' ABOMINATION WITH A FLESHY CHAINSAW FOR AN ARM
commentsCount: THAT RUSHES AT YOU AND INSTA-KILLS YOU!!!\n\nIts a typical boss fight. It chases you around the area
column16: enemies spawn EVERYWHERE
column17: and you can only slow it down and damage it by blowing up conveniently placed gas tanks at every corner of the level. Only
column18:
theres a few problems.

Number one : its the ugliest most disturbing thing ever.
Number two : this is an insane difficulty spike compared to the things before.
Number three : its dumb and ruined the atmosphere.

I was like "NOPE!" I'm sorry but I am not going through that again for any more than a third time. Uninstall!

You have been warned. You might like stuff like this
column19: but you can't deny its ♥♥♥♥♥♥ design."

reviewText:
The Resident Evil series has had its ups and its downs from the greats of  the franchise like 2,3 Code Veronica and 4 to the worst entries (survivor,0,5 Raccoon city and 6) but this game is definately a decent entry and probably the only entry since darkside chronicles that is actually fun to play.

The story of the game is basically that Jill Valentine is trying to find her partner Chris steroid junkie" Redfield who has mysteriously gone missing. This game also takes place before 5 although some things like Jills older look (though I guess that you could put that down to the fact that the game was originally done on a Nintendo console) and some of the technology available like the fact of a city built on the water are hard to believe because of the timeline.

The gameplay is a lot like that of 6 in the fact that you can move whie aiming but with the restraints of 4 in terms of melee combat. There is also a dodge feature that Jill originally had in 3 but it isn't as reliable as that one as you can never be too sure if it is going to register properly and this can be a problem as some of the enemies and bosses play out that you can damage them by dodging them when they go to charge at you whic will leave them open to attack.

You can only carry a total of three guns at one time and ammo is actually scarce if you play on normal and if you feel up to the challenge
date:
infernal. The upgrade system for guns is also back but you can never really upgrade them enough to think that you can kill everything and still complete the game with loads of ammo for every gun. The upgrades are also interchangeable so you can change what your guns atributes are if you want to tr using it to stun enemies more of veen give one of them a burst ability.

The order in which you get weapon types is a bit weird in the whole fact that you can end up getting the stronger version of a weapon type before you get the weaker versions and some of the weaker versions can only be gotten by doing things like playing he game on infernal as that is the only mode that they appear on.

Overall if you are a fan of the series of old
hoursPlayed:
and want to play a decent modern Resi game then you should definately give this game a try

score 86/100


"

reviewText:
Combination of Old RE and New RE.  There are puzzles to solve, switches to hit, and backtracking.  Everything that makes a resident evil.  This is a great example of a Resident evil done right with best of both old and new.  There are action moments but nothing over the top like RE 5 and RE 6.

You will play mostly on a ship infested by the new T-Abyss virus.  The ship is rather well crafted and interesting to navigate.  Jill and Chris are BACK!!  Just that is worth a purchase if you are a fan of old resident evil.  Story is interesting, although I didn't find any of the new characters memorable.

As for the multi-player, raid mode is very fun.  Go through stages of the single player map and take down mobs after mobs. Upgrade guns and mod them and repeat.  Gets addictive.  As long they keep this format in the upcoming Revelation 2, that will be good  as well.  --Recommend BUY

reviewText:
An obvious but enjoyable schlock side-story to the franchise with a new type enemy archetype and solid fundamental game play.

The overall game is old-school resident evil but with over the shoulder controls and the usual silly plot.
The game is as focused on over the shoulder combat as RE 4-5-6 but the plot, map, exploration and setting that remind me heavily of resident evil 2.

The inventory system is a system of magic-boxes that holds your stored list of gear and weapons and equip-able buff labels that you can find, swap and equip on weapons (closest comparison is warframe F2P game but less confusing).


The downside as I see it are that the weapon upgrade and storage system does not fit in will with the story led game-save focused, poorly chaptered game progression. The system has a strong hint of being only half-implemented or something added in mostly for new-game plus (or to allow for more weapon types) it's almost like a first attempt at a DLC platform for some cheeky bonus" paid for content but with access being strictly limited to in-game storage crate use the save-game based inventory system feels an odd choice."

reviewText:
This may be a decent game on it's own, but I'm reviewing this game from a Resident Evil fan's perspective. This game was a nightmare for me, literally. I could not force myself to play more than 15 minutes each time I try. It just doesn't have the same Resident Evil feeling that I get from previous RE 1-5. The style of the game is much different, the gameplay is weird, the monsters are weird, the story is weak, and they resort to a lot of 'jump scares' instead of the normal tension building or suspense scares. The only thing I like about this game is the graphics. This will be the first RE game I will not complete and I will go back to play RE 1-5 again. They're straying a bit too far away from the normal formula that makes the game what it is. Now it's becoming something else that we don't need, a first person shooter. This is what happens when RE meets Call of Duty or Battlefield. What next? Zombies/Monsters will know Kung Fu and have weapons as well so it'll become Tekken or Halo?

Pros:
- Good graphics.

Cons:
- Mainly jump scares. No tension building or suspense from previous titles.
- Weak story.
- Too much weapon and ammo. It's like Call of Duty meets Resident Evil.
- No zombies. At least add some. Monsters are weird and some invisible... really.

reviewText:
What's cool about this game is that the gun controls are really smooth, even if the movement controls arent. It's the Resi 4 System, you aim before you can shoot. The movement is slightly better than Resi 4, but moving while shooting is now a possibilty.
The environments on the cruise ship are also really detailed, at the expense of some shoddily-hidden load times. This game goes back to the days of the incredibly-long-to-unlock-door variety of load screens.
I know that I've barely touched on anything in the game, but this is all you really need to know about this game. It plays like Resi 4, and the environments look great.
9/10

reviewText: This is a really good game for RE fans. The campaign is really entertaining, you can get many different weapons and customize them with many weapon modifcations you find as drop or hidden in the game. The Infernal Difficulty adds an additional challenge and a few further weapon modifications. The raid mode is okay, the idea with different stages, a leveling system and weapons in different variations with upgrades has a nice touch. But it's just a small extra.\n\nThe only negative thing about this game is, that the coop mode is missing. The game would be even more fun with one.

reviewText: Out of all the RE games I've played, this was by far the least enjoyable. The new mechanics were collectively sub-par. Only new mechanic I sort of liked was the scanner. Though I don't usually enjoy swimming in games, the swimming setions were somewhat fun to go through. The Voice work and Dialouge was not up to par, the graphics very mediocre, the gameplay not that engaging, and the story felt completely irrelevant/ forgettable to the main cannon with new characters I care not to see again in any future titles. I'm glad I got this on sale or else I would have been ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 10x if I had paid full price for this. First title I really regretted buying. Sorry to the development team, thanks for the long hours trying to make somethign fun, but for this player is was all for naught.

reviewText:
What's cool about this game is that the gun controls are really smooth, even if the movement controls arent. It's the Resi 4 System, you aim before you can shoot. The movement is slightly better than Resi 4, but moving while shooting is now a possibilty.
The environments on the cruise ship are also really detailed, at the expense of some shoddily-hidden load times. This game goes back to the days of the incredibly-long-to-unlock-door variety of load screens.
I know that I've barely touched on anything in the game, but this is all you really need to know about this game. It plays like Resi 4, and the environments look great.
9/10

reviewText: I'm not sure what precisely other people see in this game. Is it just nostalgia for old Resident Evil because RE5 and RE6 were so awful? You can try to put lipstick on a pig all you want, this game is decidedly medicore. The old tank like controls for RE aren't the least bit compelling without a decent atmosphere to help it along. The optimization attempt during the conversion from a portable platform (Nintendo 3DS) to PC is laughably substandard. It looks like middle-gen PS2 game at best.\n\nI realize that plot and dialogue (Yay for Jessica's sweet ♥♥♥!") have never been the priority for any RE games

reviewText:
This may be a decent game on it's own, but I'm reviewing this game from a Resident Evil fan's perspective. This game was a nightmare for me, literally. I could not force myself to play more than 15 minutes each time I try. It just doesn't have the same Resident Evil feeling that I get from previous RE 1-5. The style of the game is much different, the gameplay is weird, the monsters are weird, the story is weak, and they resort to a lot of 'jump scares' instead of the normal tension building or suspense scares. The only thing I like about this game is the graphics. This will be the first RE game I will not complete and I will go back to play RE 1-5 again. They're straying a bit too far away from the normal formula that makes the game what it is. Now it's becoming something else that we don't need, a first person shooter. This is what happens when RE meets Call of Duty or Battlefield. What next? Zombies/Monsters will know Kung Fu and have weapons as well so it'll become Tekken or Halo?

Pros:
- Good graphics.

Cons:
- Mainly jump scares. No tension building or suspense from previous titles.
- Weak story.
- Too much weapon and ammo. It's like Call of Duty meets Resident Evil.
- No zombies. At least add some. Monsters are weird and some invisible... really.

reviewText:
RER is alright for a few hours, but I could not recommend it. It's close though, but I think a positive review with warnings and reservations, would be too highly rated.

I have played it for ten hours and I am bored now. I have no motivation even to finish it to see what the story is. I will most likely drag myself through to the end though.

It started OK though. I liked the enemies a lot, because they were properly freaky; weird things that look like they can not see. However it soon became apparent there was a nasty stuttery bug. Every ten seconds the RER freezes for half-a-second, to a second, and it happens right through the game. No fix for it online. (Only a fix for it in RER2.)

Secondly, the graphics are weak for a 2012 release. They would have been average in 2006. There is not one 'stop to look at the graphics moment' ever. Not only are the textures poor, but there is not one image of anything worth looking at. Regardless of graphics detail. Everything is just average.

Initially though I was loving it. The game moved on quite quickly, because I was not getting stuck much, or dying over and over. I put aside my negative feelings and played. However as time went on I realised the entire map was just being re-used, endlessly. In other words it should be called Resident Evil Backtracking. It's a maze too.

By about 7 hours play I was bored and I was hoping it was going to end soon. Then I was hoping it would end now. At ten hours I thought I had beaten the last boss - great. Nope, there was a filler in, which took me back to a previously used map, and had me slowly moving around it.

Pap pap pap goes the pistol. The gun that you always avoid in games. They make you use it lots. Really there is nothing more to latch onto, to remain interested.

The good points are some of the enemies, the atmosphere intially, and the fact you don't die too often.

reviewText:
You want Resident Evil Revelations? I will give you revelation -> this game sux. I could not stand playing for more than 3 hours. Just... impossible.

TL-DR : I got this game for free. And I did not even get my money's worth. I do not recommend it at all.This was the first Resident Evil game I played and I believe it will be the last.

What is this game about? Protagonist is a crippled person, uncappable of anything but slow walk. So you charge at your enemies with agility of 95 yo grandpa with clutches. You can not even move a chair if it blocks your path. You shoot zombies that hardly notice it. You scan desks with scanner to find hidden ammo. You look for keys to find doors to get you to doors that you need to find key to open, to get to door that you have no card to open and need to slowly walk to another door that magically opened at your convenience to get it...

Gameplay is terrible. Terrible. You can not dodge or block in normal way, nor jump or crouch. Not even run. You just walk with zombies behind you. And if you shoot them, even in the head, they do not even react, they do not flinch. They are not thrown back even if you shoot them with shotgun to the chest at arms length. And you must be almost stationary to shoot. No Run and Gun. Nope. If you try that, you swing knife at enemies... You want to spray them down while backing like hell? Nope, not here.

Ah, there is a door! (the corridors are a few metres long, then there is a door. Always a door... every few steps. And the monsters disappear or appear when you go through that door. And you always close the door behind you. Smart). There is some debris blocking your path, that you coul walk over (not even need to jump) ? Too bad, you need to take a de-tour.
There is NO place for cyber-athletics, no agility.  No using corners, ducking, running back and charging at enemy when you see fit. Nope, not here.You just walk at enemies at the speed of dying turtle, shoot them (shooting makes no difference until enemy suddenly drops dead) and open doors.
Ah, and eat a plant that grows everywhere to magicaly restore your health. And use super-advanced scanner to find ammo you can not see otherwise.

Tasks are extremely dull and boring Every zombie runs at you. Every one tries to kill you. Unless the zombie carries a key that you need. Then, for some reason, it runs away from you... and you need to chase it to the start of the level, so the game  seems longer and not so linear. So you end up walking here and there like a confused freshman looking for his class. Go get the key to get through this door. Ah god, why not learn how to pick that locks, they seem to be everywhere...

Shooting does not feel natural. It has no real effect on the enemy, apart from lowering their health bar. So you are stationary, can not run, and can not use guns to clear some space. You just stand, walk back slowly and shoot. It is extremely boring. No satisfaction in killing enemies, no thrill in battless. None at all.

The atmosphere is not like in a horror movie. It feels like in a parody of a horror movie. There is actually no atmosphere at all. The game controls feel so unnatural that it just will not let you fall into the story. The battles are so dull you will get no rush of adrenaline. They try to make it scary, and they fail miserably. A zombie attacked me from a washing machine... seriously? A lot of jumps scenes that try to scare you, but they simply do not work at all... The only scary" moment is when the game crashes and you are afraid of losing your save file.

You want a good horror-shooter game? Go and buy Metro 2033 redux and thank me later. Leave this be. It is not worth your time."

reviewText:
This is a step in both the right and wrong direction for the Resident Evil series at large-
the atmosphere is closer to what the older iterations of the series felt like, with dingy corridors
and a sense of threat absent from other recent versions of the game. It offers a nautical resident
evil 'experience', for better or for worse depending on the taste of the player. There is a horror
of a sort here, but it is underused considering the setting and isolation of the sea.

The controls handle well, but the fact you have to use the mouse to shoot, without being given the option to map it to the keyboard, is a massive drawback- Resident Evil 5 allowed you to do so in its own PC port, so it seems inexcusible to have it absent here. Otherwise, most of the other controls are no different from previous iterations. Being able to charge one's physical attacks is satisfying but it breaks up the frenetic flow of combat a little too much.

The further lack of an inventory system again moves away from the crux of what has come to have been expected from the series; it feels too deliberate an attempt at distancing itself other games. In addition, the lack of variety in enemy types is also rather disappointing, although the designs of those included are suitably grotesque. The scanner, however, is one addition which I think works well, though it has teething troubles here from being typecast in a similar vein to the 'vision' mechanic present in recent Batman, Lara Croft and Hitman games.

Altogether, this is a back-to-basics Resident Evil game, which it strengthened and weakened by this move, but its glaring flaws for me cannot be balanced by its positive ones. Go for the first Dead Space game instead- it is a more effective and streamlined horror shooter game.

reviewText:
Bought this in the humble bundle deal.

Very odd title. It plays like an older Resident Evil game. It's heavy on the wandering around looking for where to go next, solve the next puzzle. It seems like a step back from the other titles such as Resident Evil 4 and 5. The graphics are certainly inferior. The sound is ok.

I believe it was originally developed as a 3DS title, which frankly explains a lot.

For die hard fans of the series only, it's a bit of a struggle to play and not very enjoyable. The action/shooter elements of the game feel like something from 15 years ago. The plot is hilariously bad. The maps are confusing.

My advice: Go straight to Revelations 2. Much better game.

reviewText:
Resident Evil Revelations is another step in the downward trend of the Resident Evil franchise. The fact that the HD version came out after the sixth installment is what makes it seem better than it actually is, because frankly anything is better than Resident Evil 6,

The setting is appropriate for a horror game, having been explored previously in the series with Resident Evil Gaiden and Resident Evil Dead Aim. One cannot criticize this story without doing so for the other games in the series because it's just as silly as the previous games, albeit without any of the charming character of Resident Evil 1 or 4 (both directed by Shinji Mikami, coincidentally).

It's a shame that they had to complicate such a simple story by going back and forth in time making the player control a variety of characters, most of them unecessary, a consequence of Capcom's decision to incorporate co-op or AI partner all the time. What ends up happening is that you have lots of names, throwaway characters and  a breaking of pace as a result of playing out irrelevant events in the story (playing as Chris in a boat to show him boarding the cruise ship for instance).

The gameplay is a step forward from Resident Evil 5, and a more sober affair than the mess that is Resident Evil 6's combat system. You move and shoot/stab and can occasionally stun an enemy to perform a high powered physical attack, which is satisfying. Less so are some of the enemies with instant death kills, which are a little cheap, but it's nothing new for the series. The gameplay does become tiring though, because the enemies are designed as bullet sponges and are very repetitive. That's not to say the zombies in the previous games are not, but they were shorter experiences as well.
Thankfully, the quick time events from RE4 and RE5 take a break in the game, being relegated to escaping an enemy's grasp and turning valves.

Being originally a 3DS game, some of the geometry and facial expressions do look a bit basic, and some of the textures are not up to PS3/360/PC standards, but it's not a bad looking game, it looks on par with early generation graphics. It's certainly well optimized and runs better than Resident Evil 4 Ultimate, which is mind boggling.

The difficulty of the game is balanced, but with some spikes that detract from the TV series approach and pace of it, namely in the boss battles that can be quite infuriating in the first tries. The Infernal difficulty mode is different from RE5's Professional mode but just as silly. Instead of overpowered attackers, the enemies become even bigger bullet sponges, turning the game into a brick wall, though it softens as one progresses and gets better gear. It's  a far cry from the challenging but fair Real Survival Mode of the 2002 remake, it's just pulling the bars to make it as unbalanced as it can be.
To add to the longevity is the Raid Mode, which is a worse time waster than Mercenaries because it features levelling and each level takes way longer to complete, and the difficulty ramps up to where you need to grind quite a bit through the ship you're already sick of traversing and the enemies you're already sick of fighting from the campaign.

It's a better game than what came after, and does many things better than Resident Evil 5, but it lacks character and importance in the overall series. For a game that's called Revelations, removing it from the story arch does no difference at all and makes it an entry that can fade to obscurity.

reviewText:
Better than 6, worse than 4, probably on par with 5 (less racist), worse than any of the games that came out before the movie. Okay to pick up on a sale, don't buy it if you want a game to bite into.

Raid mode will make up more than 75% of your play time if you're going for 100% completion- and it's basically a master class in the flaws of the game mechanics, not to mention insanely repetitive and grindy.

Some of the things I glazed over during campaign mode became glaringly obvious in raid mode:

enemies spawn from nowhere and most have no movement sounds
too many enemies have instant kill moves
healing is too easy, but so is getting hit
monsters attack through corners
monster hit zones clip through walls
enemies disappear when they get too close to the camera
soundtrack is terrible and floods out the monster sounds- which blend together anyway
Enemies take forever to kill (spent 10 minutes shooting a single enemy once)
dodging is annoying- basically a QTE, not a proactive action
enemies can spawn on top of you and hit you before you can draw your weapon, etc
You get no invincibility frames (would be a good thing in a better designed game)
buttons are mostly multi-function, so if you try to leave a room, but a monster is waiting to be punched...
at higher difficulties, recovery time decreases, so stunning is usually a nonviable strategy (making for a more boring game)
evels are all based on campaign mode
levels are designed for coop play
coop is dead
There's an experience system (WHY?), heavily capping your progress and requiring you to replace your gear
the gear system is heavily inspired by diablo
you will get a viable weapon one in every four runs (two+ hours of gameplay, assuming you don't die)
It felt like they decided that the answer to challenging players is to constantly spawn enemies from two directions+ (meaning it's geared towards coop play) and to make invisible, noiseless enemies with instant kills. Memorizing spawn points, maximizing damage per bullet and relying on my reflexes was fun for about 5 hours. The remaining 40...

Grinding for gear has never been fun. And who makes a horror" game where most of the monsters don't make noise moving? Sound is probably the most important aspect of horror. Lack thereof should be a unique feature of one type of monster
date: at most.\n\nThat may sound awesome (it's SUPPOSED to be challenging)
recommended: except there's so much of it
hoursPlayed: it's all so similar and takes SO LONG.\n\nI'd say if raid mode took <1/3 of the time and the fun toys dropped BEFORE the last level so you could actually use them while clearing it
voteText: this might be a worthwhile game."

reviewText:
At it's core, Revelations is basically an experiment for Capcom. They tried to do something different than what they've been doing since RE4, and it paid off. While there may not be zombies or traditional B.O.W.s in this game (other than so many dozens of hunters) it is the closest thing to a classic Resident Evil title in years.

Revelations covers the initial days of the BSAA and shows some of the events preceding Resident Evil 5. Evidently the world is in a state where they can build solar powered cities that float on the sea, but not stop making bioweapons. The story revolves around solving the mystery of how BOWs keep showing up in the area with ties to the terrorist organization that got the city destroyed. Obviously, this leads in classic RE fashion to an overly complicated environment - a cruise ship which frankly looks too Spencerian and not remotely like a vacation cruise ship - that, of course, houses a secret bio-weapons research lab.

In addition to the lab, almost all of the new ancillary characters are revealed to be double agents or traitors, continuing with the trends of RE, and are working for a mysterious organization or for themselves. Thematically, Revelations really is about as close as possible to the older games. It also has plenty of horrible characters and character dialog - between Jessica's forced attempts at appearing sexy to players, Quint and Keiths ridiculous Internet nerd/black guy with a life" cliches
date: and Raymond and Rachels haircuts - What the actual f? - the cheese level is easily higher than RE1.\n\nThere is no co op in this game's campaign
recommended: either. You are on your own. Rarely ever will your AI teammate be anywhere near you and when they are they truly will not be helpful. As for environment
hoursPlayed: Capcom did a pretty decent job. Again the cruise ship looks nothing like a cruise ship and it's ridiculous
voteText: but what it does is emulate the claustrophobia and grandeur of the Spencer Mansion.\n\nIn addition to the only true Resident Evil plot in years

reviewText:
Seriously, this is got to be the cheapest game i've ever played in my entire life. Nothing, literally nothing in this game stands out as redeemable as a video game.

This game tries so hard to grind gamplay hour out of so little content it is absolutely ridiculous:

1. Very little savepoints. I'm fine with not having manual savepoints, but autosave every other half an hour in the story, really?
2. Instant kill boss fights, and even that, each death sends you another half an hour back BEFORE the boss fight, which is completely unnecessary
3. Instant kill grunts. Yep, even some grunts can instant kill you, and guess what, back another half an hour you go.
4. Absolutely no indication of sequence of events. Some random guy handing me a key is a perfect indication of the pool finished draining, Really? Are the developers even trying at this point?
5. Backtracking. For the little amount of content it has, it makes you backtrack the same area, FIVE TIMES. Each time you get a new key, you go back to the same area to unlock new doors, so you can get more keys to come back to the same area to unlock even more doors, absolutely ridiculously lazy.

For a game released in 2013, this game has absolutely nothing to offer that stands out from the rest, I can name tons of survival horror games that beats this crap out of the water (BioShock, Dead Space, etc) in terms of gameplay, story telling and graphics.

Words cannot express how much I despise this game, for the cheap lazy piece of crap it is.

reviewText: This has to be the second worst Resident Evil game I've ever played. Out of the new set, you have 4, 5, 6, Raccoon City, then this. This only succeeds at being better than Raccoon City, but that's up for debate since that title wasn't actually made by Capcom. It was a game made by someone else, being skinned to look like a Resident Evil game to sell it. It's definitely the worst, no question, but if you ignore it and only count official Capcom made titles, then this is actually the bottom of the barrel. And that's still quite an accomplishment because RE 6 is just terrible. This game can't even rise to the low bar that RE 6 set. It's sad to see a series get worse with each title rather than better. But let's not get off topic, this is a review for Revelations, specifically, the PC port. I don't own a DS. I own PC, this on PC, and am reviewing this version of it only.\n\nSo what do we got? What we got here is basically a cheap port from the DS. Despite touting how improved the graphics are for PC, it is not up to par with the other titles. There's still tons of low res textures everywhere in the game that they couldn't bother to update. One positive note is that there aren't many cutscenes. RE 6 was infested with more of them than zombies. But the graphics aren't really what kills this game for me... it's the cockteasing. They tease us with a ship that's suppose to have open exploration, much like the older games. A lot of its interior is actually modelled to feel similar to the classic mansion. A haunted/infested cruise ship is the perfect setting for a Resident Evil game, and offers a lot of possible stages. Sounds great, right? Well, it has some of your open exploration... then the other 90% of the game is a linear corridor shooter like the other games. You're also teased with Jill making a return, but again, barely get much time to actually play her. Too much of the game(hint: any is too much) is spent being forced to play these other ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you'll only inevitably hate as much as possible and never want to actually play. You're forced to play them, entirely against your will, and will rush their sections as fast as you can because you just want to get back to Jill. They're literally wasting your time. My point is that Capcom found a great potential to make another game, then proceeds to waste that potential, pouring it all right down the tube, in every possible way they can. This is another shoulda woulda coulda" title

reviewText:
The game is a terrible console port.

Textures are of a laughably schizophrenic resolution, the controls are frustratingly clunky and the story is stupid even for resident evils standards.

Several times I caught myself wondering why I was still playing the game and I'm just glad I bought it on sale.

Steer clear of this game even if you are a fan of the series.

If I were to use a rating system I'd give it 3/10.

reviewText: I'm a big fan of horror in games. I loved Resident Evil 4, even though it shed its horror mid way in, and I tolerated Resident Evil 5 because the coop gameplay was fun. Revelations, unfortunately, is not the return to horror it's been marketed as. Instead, this game feels incredibly like an android/iOS game. There is very little complexity; no inventory, no management of herbs or ammo. Environments are restricted making it feel more like a rail shooter than anything else where your only choice is forward or back (akin to Killer7, a much better game). Characters and plot are boring. Skip this one.

reviewText:
I played this game all the way through a few weeks after beating Resident Evil 4 for the first time.

Pros:
- scarce ammo and limited weapons added to the horror atmosphere
- genuinely scary at times
- challenging!

Cons:
- scanning mechanic is just god awful in my opinion
- weapon upgrade system blows... HARD
- confusing map system
- most of the game is backtracking through places you've already been
- some portions of the game drag on

If you're looking for a game that fills the void in your heart that Resident Evil 4 left, don't bother with this game.  Honestly, I would rather replay Resident Evil 4 than play this again.  I would also recommend playing through the Dead Space series for the horror elements you crave with much better game design than this.

reviewText:
I can't even lie but this is, by far, the worst game I have ever played. At this point I can't remember one where the story or the gameplay is so lame/stupid or worse than that. Let me explain:

- 1st I am on a ship, that has different levels, which is good but the level design is boring, blocked by rooms and doors that open only at certain points in the story. I can't say that I like it, since it's one of the worst way to play a game, worst than liniar gameplay.
- 2nd the other player, controlled by A.I., it's like it's not even there. He can't hit anything, it's use is zero, while the mobs that attack me will always ignore him.
- 3rd the weapons... wow I can't imagine anyone designing worse weapons than these. Honest there's no game in the world that has a worse weapon design.
- 4th the mobs... hell this game has also the most nonimaginative zombies ever created as enemies in a game. They move like a zombie but also do the damage as a tank, while bullets seems to hurt them like... a fly.
- while the checkpoint system is ok, hell ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ console players can't do ♥♥♥♥ without checkpoints and autoaim, so why not bring it on the PC version... why do we even bother with having mouse + keyboard?
- I died so many times in this game, more than in all my other games played (around 500 games at least). Hell I die at CS less than in this game and mostly because I either run out of ammo or I have to run from some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mobs... that spawn till the end of time (I meant spawn at infinit).
I have tried to play every single Resident Evil game and well... all I can say is that these Capcom guys have zero skills at porting game from their ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ consoles to PC. I really hate autoaim, I hate the bad control that comes with ♥♥♥♥ ports, I have the zero A.I. the companion NPC has, I hate the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ checkpoint system, I am starting to have Capcom. I might buy the company and fire everyone, just to save their players's souls.
- I am absolutely speechless on how lame this game is. You need a lot of menus, just to start a simple game. Why? Is that hard to work hard and change the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ console ♥♥♥♥, to simple but efficient PC interface? Why do you even bother launching the game on PC then? Just to see how much frustration a player can feel? The question is... if I do the same to you, will you like it?

This is by far the worst game that I have ever played. The level of frustration felt while playing... it's close to +infinite.

Sadly my score is just 2/10. I can say a lot of bad things, at this point I can't see one that is good.

P.S. Also one can't play in raid the levels. unless he finished those levels in the campaign... which I won't really bother to... finish.

reviewText:
Alright where to begin with this mess. It's a ♥♥♥♥ poor port of the 3DS version of the game (which is even worse than this, so thank Capcom for porting it... I guess?). There's higher resolutions and gameplay changes to Raid Mode so players can't expoit the lewt drop system... but it doesn't stop save editors and trainers... so the point of that was? What exactly? Waste time? Yeah... sounds like it.

The plot is contrived and stupid... the twists to the plot were obvious so there's really no *gasp, SURPRISE!* moments. If you've been following Resident Evil up until now then you'll be pleasently surprised that you and non-fans are on the same page... I dunno where all these extra characters came from but they suck balls and lack personality. I was lost right from the get go and I'm a huge RE fan... back when RE was RE any way... like the first 4 games.

There's just too many new faces in this game and it makes me feel like I missed some game that was unreleased. (which I didn't because there is no such thing) These events are supposed to take place between Resident Evil 4 and 5 but they don't do a very good job of explaining how Jill and Chris wound up knowing these new characters or how they got in to the situation they're in... they kind of just banter back and forth between all the bullet spraying about a time they took a trip in Aspin together... or some trivial ♥♥♥♥ like that.

It's a bit confusing and made me feel detached from the plot. I figured this game was going to stick closer to the roots of Resident Evil but it's just as bad as Resident Evil 4 for missing the point entirely. Instead of fighting Spanards or African's you fight Crab People and other mutated sea dwelling crustations... oh yeah, and wolves... because you know, they have to have some kind of canine enemy in the game to trick people in to thinking they're playing a Resident Evil game. Still hanging on to the original dog jump scare from  RE1, I see, Capcom?

The game is stale and drab the entire way through, enemies are more annoying than ever to kill and require you to learn the dodge system or get locked in to a one hit kill death... pretty obnoxious. Also I've never seen more annoying enemies that have weak spots on their back side and require you to learn a ridiculously long move set in order to get a 3 second opening.

Hunters are back... yay? Not nearly as intimidating as before... in RE1 a single hunter meant about a 70% chance of death if you didn't have a magnum handy... In this game you fight groups of 3 or 4, no issues... it's the action portion of these newer RE's that make my ♥♥♥♥ soft. If I wanted to play Gears of War, I would do so.

Alright on to the multiplayer, it's non-existant for the campaign (I guess that's what Capcom meant by going back to the roots"... because I see no other resemblance to previous RE games) so grab a friend and head in to "Raid Mode"... A mode designed to bore the living ♥♥♥♥ out of you. You run small gauntlets through fragmented sections of the game with a static set of enemies
date:
always positioned the same way until you memorize not to get hit and make sure you kill everything... sounds like fun? It's not.

If you're not communicating then expect drop outs during a 20 minute long mission with randoms. (good luck finding anyone who plays this mess now) There's 20 Levels with 3 difficulties all of which must be completed to unlock the bonus stage.

The bonus stage is about a 40 minute romp through the entire ship where you have to fight the end boss
hoursPlayed: once in normal form and once in uber form if you're on level 50... so you can

reviewText:
I'm going to give this game a pre-finish review...  I will add and change it later as needed.

So... I'm just going to come out and say it...  This game SUCKS.  That's the short answer.  To be fair, I knew it was going to suck from the demo I played before it came out but that's besides the point.

The long version.
Cons:
Scanning for items.  What.  The.  Hell!   What kind of lame BS mechanic is that!  These supposed people who have dealt with all manner of monsters ranging from rabid acid spitting spiders all the way up to Nemesis and more suddenly cant see the herb that's nestled between a storage rack and sink?  I call BS!
Episodic. This.  On its own is a horrible idea for a Resident Evil game.  It kills the immersion in the story at every story and episode break.  I do not even mind the character swapping to see different sides of the story as much when compared to this flaw!
Jessica.  I would be making blond jokes for DAYS if in-fact she was blond.  The sad part is, shes not.  How she managed to get into the same category as Chris and Jill is beyond me!  WHO THE HELL WEARS HIGH HEELS TO A BLOODY FROZEN MOUNTION!!!  And then whines when her feet hurt!  She acts like the standard clingy girlfriend who wants to know everything about you and your past when there is no reason to be asking about it!  Honestly, Id have fed her to the zombies the first chance i got >.>
The story.  So far the story is...kinda Blah.  Its not the worst I have seen. ((Cough cough RE5 and 6 Cough Cough)) but its still up there.
The inventory.  Where the hell did it go?  Whats with the F buttons half ♥♥♥♥♥ inventory???  Give us back what we had in RE4 or before cause this sucks.  I'm ignoring the whole “Presss TAB to insta heal” thing.
The map.  Why is there a mini map?Netural: (This is here because its both good and bad... take it as you will)
Jill.  More to the point, her outfit.  Sexy...but no!  Just no!  Skin tight leathers(I think)?  Why would you do that?  It was not necessary...   BUT....  Appreciated none the less.
Mouse movement.  Its ok, not great though.  It has a slight tendency to jump around or the sensitivity alters randomly.  Still playable however.Good:
Movement.  The game plays smooth for movement.
Graphics. Also OK.  The models are decent, the areas are good and detailed.  Some weird effects with water and goo but that is OK
Sub-weapon use.  Able to just press G to chuck grenades while aiming?  Yes please.  One of those things that you just do not thing about until its given to you.Its kinda hard to find anything good about this game currently to be honest...

I will add more as needed.

EDIT:
I dont know how, but this game got worse...  Now, we have Jill, Chris, The chick from Legaly Blond, 2 of the 3 stooges(Slapstick and all), the emo redhead guy and that other guy whos name escapes me...  This is some horable writing coupled with terrable acting.  Also...Who the hell flys to a ship on a chopper and doesnt check the name on the boat before landing!!!  Its right there!  You have the technology!  Im done with this game.  I cant bring myself to finish it just because of the afore mentioned.  To say nothing about the god aweful story.  The best this game deserves is 4/10, thats it.

reviewText:
This has to be the worst Resident Evil game i have played after Resident Evil 6 and the worst of em all the abomination that is RE: Racoon City, after having played those and 4/5 this game feels like a huge step back due to the limitations of the 3DS when it has been ported to a bigger console/Pc. Everything feels cramped into tight spaces due to the small screen of the 3DS, the game is prob a great feat for the power of a 3DS but everything looks worse than RE 4/5/6 on the PC.

The story in this game has to be the worst ive seen in RE, its absolutely ♥♥♥♥ poor with crap dialogue and development. The story never managed to grab me like the older games it feels all over the place with episodes dedicated to some new characters that are supposed to act as comic relief Keith/other guy etc." but it just doesnt do it well. All the new characters except from Raymond are beyond bad and borders more over to a dumb group of BSAA/FBC ? members and ruins the overall mysticim from the characters we already knew before this game with their crappy voices and 1 dimensional depth.

The gameplay has some good moments over the 12 episodes and approx. 14 hours it took for me to complete it with a good amount of intensity and creepy atmosphere but the pacing is overall poorly done. I was expecting this to be a slower RE game compared to the later console offerings but the game is way more action packed than i expected
date: theres really no room for breathing between the episodes. 1 episode you will be running down corridors filled with enemies and a timer while in the next episode you will be unarmed for the whole episode and chased in most of the rooms
recommended:
there are even alot of swimming parts adding more to the overused intensity making the game overall a too intense experience.

Theres some new elements included to the series that are some of the worst additions ive seen in RE games

1. The 3d map is completely useless making moving around the ship a hassle early on when the game unfolds new areas.

2. The worst bit "The Genesis scanner thing" This has to be the absolute worst thing added to a RE game i have ever played. Its a sad excuse for making the game longer than it should be
hoursPlayed: having to scan the environment all the time you enter a new room for ammo and hidden items doesnt only take away the focus on the crappy plot and gameplay but also makes playing it a chore.\n\nThat said the game still gives you hope for the series later installments a bit after the crappy RE 6 and RCity and fans should still play this as its still have some good bits. The game should probably have been released in between RE 4 and 5 though. I think it actually might be best to purchase it for 3DS aswell as its the original system for the game and might be a better experience on it. Not sure what Capcom was thinking with announcing a sequel to this game though considering how poor the story was in the 1st game
voteText: but Capcom hasnt made sense for a long time now.\n\nRating :  6.5/10"

reviewText: Resident Evil® Revelations returns redefined for PC complete with high quality HD visuals, enhanced lighting effects and an immersive sound experience. This latest version of Resident Evil Revelations will also deliver additional content including a terrifying new enemy, extra difficulty mode, integration with ResidentEvil.net and improvements to Raid Mode. Raid Mode, which was first introduced to the series in the original version of Resident Evil Revelations, sees gamers play online in co-op mode or alone in single player taking on the hordes of enemies across a variety of missions whilst leveling up characters and earning weapon upgrades. New weapons, skill sets, and playable characters including Hunk, take the Raid Mode experience to new depths.\n\nThe critically acclaimed survival horror title takes players back to the events that took place between Resident Evil® 4 and Resident Evil® 5, revealing the truth about the T-Abyss virus. Resident Evil Revelations features series favorites Jill Valentine and Chris Redfield, plus their respective BSAA partners - Parker Luciani and Jessica Sherawat. The action begins on board a supposedly abandoned cruise ship, the ‘Queen Zenobia’, where horrors lurk around every corner, before players head for the mainland and the devastated city of Terragrigia. With limited ammo and weapons available, the race is on to survive the horror of Resident Evil Revelations.

reviewText:
I'm gonna cut this game some slack for being a port from a mobile console - the graphics actually don't look that bad for a PSP game, they did a solid job porting it. The atmosphere and the new character Parker also give a nice, eerie introduction to the ship that the majority of the game takes place on.

And that's about all I can say that's good about this game.

I cannot fathom why people said this game was better than Resident Evil 6 - the gameplay is watered down (PSP port, okay), the voice acting is dull, the story is uninteresting and lacks focus much more than Resident Evil 6 did. And the worst part is the character design. If you thought Jill's catsuit from Resident Evil 5 was bad, wait till you see Rachel and Jessica in this game. Just google those names under Resident Evil and you will see what I mean.

Point is, don't get this game. Even if you don't mind sexualised character design, there is just nothing good on offer here.
