reviewText:
Resident Evil: Revelations is a departure from where the main, numbered series has been going, and the game works and is a fun, scary blast despite a few disappointments.

The game takes place in between RE4 and RE5, but the storyline has nothing to do with the main series at all. Aside from a few characters (Jill, and Chris) and a few organizations mentioned (BSAA, Umbrella), everything is wholly original making this game a good standalone for those curious about the franchise. The story is all about spies, bio-terrorism, counter-terrorism, and attempts to go into some interesting psychology behind the villain's motivations but it falls a little flat. The story is told with that same goofy, almost-not-b-movie quality that has become the staple flavor for the series, and for a tale spanning countries with some really fun twists and turns that tone works surprisingly well. Couple that with the game's episodic chapters and it feels like you're watching a low-budget TV show from the 90s, and it's great.

The gameplay really isn't anything too different than the rest of the series. It has an over the shoulder, third person perspective, shooting certain points on enemies will weaken them and allow you to melee them to great effect (I still think that Chris's fists are more powerful than shotgun blasts). For the majority of the campaign you have an AI partner following you around, ala RE5, except this partner doesn't need your healing items or ammo and can't be controlled by another player, which is actually an improvement for this game. Despite it's similarities to 5, the game actually made me frightened, which only the first game (the Gamecube remake) managed to do. The atmosphere is very well set up, and one of the main locations in the game requires back tracking, but it's done so well you feel like you're running hopelessly in circles. The most frightening, and challenging, part of the game actually has you search for a dead comrade, only to find she has been resurrected as a disgusted squid-mutant-lady, and you then have to hunt her throughout the games main setting, which is a creepy, derelict boat that sways slowly beneath your feet. This moment is when the game really, truly shines as you never know when she's going to pop out and scream in a girlish voice, found you!" Unfortunately the rest of the game is nowhere near as scary
date: but it is a lot more tense than any of the resident evil games after the REmake and RE0.\n\nMy disappointments in the game are minor
recommended: but still important. After defeating the squid-mutant-lady

reviewText:
I cannot believe I am saying this but this game is the first reasonably good Resident Evil game since Resident Evil Code Veronica.

The game's atmosphere is engaging and filled with suspense.
The monsters actually surprise you and put up a fight most of the time.
The story could be better, it begins shrouded by mystery, and when it clears up it reveals another political war.
The AI sucks, a lot. The monsters ignore your AI partner and go directly for you, and your AI partner does not do a thing. RE 5 AI was better.
The game is very short.

Overall it is the first game since RE 4 that brings the classic Resident Evil feeling from the first games. I highly recommend to all classic Resident Evil fans out there.

reviewText:
A straight-up upscaled port of a 3-year-old 3DS game, which retails for $20, sold for $50.

The campaign is short, the levels are extremely cramped and linear, and load times (though hidden) are frequent, as befitting the original hardware for which they were designed.

All that being said, if you can catch it for the price of the 3DS version or less, it's a far better Resident Evil game than Capcom's latest fiascos, keeping more in line with the gameplay style of RE5, and making an attempt to return to spookiness and atmosphere over explosions and bolo ties. There are even tense underwater sections, and the return of the master of unlocking!

The cherry on top is raid mode, an online cooperative mode for two players, where you fight your way through snippets of the campaign, albeit with more aggressive enemy placement. You collect loot, unlock characters and costumes, and attempt to score well to earn points for purchasing and upgrading skills and equipment. It ties into Capcom's bizarre RE.net website, as well, so you can get a little more use out of the damn thing if you made one for RE6.

Overall, a pretty great game, and something of a return to form for the Resident Evil series.

reviewText:
An HD Port of an early 3DS release, Resident Evil Revelations ended up being a much more faithful representation of the franchise as a whole than it's widely panned console brethren Resident Evil 6.

While RE: Revelations was originally advertised as a sort of prequel to Resident Evil 5, about all is shares with the previous title is it's main protagonists, Jill Valentine and Chris Redfield, and their current positions as field agents of the counter bioterrorism NGO BSAA.

Revelations brings subtle improvements to RE5's controls, in particular the oft requested ability to strafe, and includes new functionality such as equipment tuning.  Weapons are now socketed equipment able to hold a number of custom components that augment their performance, these components effects range from higher magazine capacity to greater damage output and faster firing rates, among other more unique effects I'll let you discover.

Revelations also features the Genesis system.  The Genesis is a handheld scanner not far off from Metroid Prime's scan visor, and quickly proves to be just as useful, allowing the player to locate easter eggs, hidden items, research dead enemies for healing items, and so forth.  The downside is you'll end up spending quite a bit of time behind the Genesis HUD, which can deflate the horror athmosphere for some.

The story of Revelations brings the series back to it's zany horror roots, this time mixed with a bit of old school Ace Combat crazy.  Some time after the fictional island utopia of Terragrigia is laid waste by solar sattelite weapons, Jill and Chris find themselves on opposite sides of the globe following the trail of a bioterrorism organization named Veltro, with Jill's search bringing her to an abandoned cruise liner named the Queen Zenobia.  In Resident Evil tradition things quickly go off the rails for both, and the story becomes a globetrotting race against time to unearth the plans of whomever, or whatever, has taken residence on the doomed ship.

The story also spends a significant amount of time fleshing out the BSAA and the people who work there,  and the game occasionally puts the player in control of a few of Jill and Chris' fellow agents following up on leads the former have discovered.  It provides an interesting look at an organization that has become the series sucessor to the ill fated S.T.A.R.S. unit of the first game.

Graphically the HD upgrade makes the game somewhat above average in visual polish, and a few bland environment textures notwithstanding it looks pretty good for an uprezzed 3DS game.  The character models can be slightly off, Jill's being the most noticable, it would have been nice if the character models and full motion video cutscenes had an upgrade pass as well.

Revelations has several other flaws, the transition to PC has led to some glaring omissions such as the lack of the laser sight present on it's handheld counterpart.  It would have also been nice if the PC upgrade could have had an increase in enemy variety, as most of the undead creatures you'll be facing on the Zeonbia share the same general design.  None of these issues are gamebreaking, however.  And while the game does feature on rails sequences, they're nowhere near the frequency and general unplayability found in those of Resident Evil 6.

Bottom line, this is an incredibly successful if somewhat flawed transition from handheld to PC.  And even for those who can't agree on whether Resident Evil 2 or Resident Evil 4 are the pinnacle of the series, there's something for everyone to enjoy.  So if you're a fan of Resident Evil or Survival Horror, you can't go wrong with Resident Evil Revelations.

reviewText:
Resident Evil Revelations / Biohazard Revelations seems like a new game but it was released in 2012 on the Portable gaming platform that is the 3DS and then, a year later, on the XB360, PS3, Wii U and naturally, PC. The game itself was surprisingly decent. I had a whole lot of fun with it and a little piece of advice, the game plays way better with the Keyboard + Mouse scheme (a word of advice though, disable the mouse acceleration though!). With the XB360 gamepad, the aiming was all jerky and you end up missing so many shots.

As for the game itself, it was so much superior to the pathetic Resident Evil 6 which in my opinion was one of the worse RE game ever made. But this one, RE: Revelations, redeemed itself well enough in its atmosphere setting, the gameplay mechanics, voice acting and even the music department.

To make it short, this is the game RE6 should have been but wasn't unfortunately!

For a ported game, the only big noticeable CON would be the graphical and visual side of the game.

PROS:
+Ghost ship horror atmosphere.
+Decent campaign length.
+Neat characters models (well modelized, especialy Jill's Azz!).
+Auto-sufficient" A.I. (partner manage itself so no need to run at him/her to heal).
+Nice soundtrack.
+Replay value with the Raid Mode or if you seek achievements completion.

CONS:
-Awful textures.
-Weak controls with XB360 gamepad.
-Messy story.
-Weak A.I. but helpful at times as it brings the enemies to itself.
-Limited enemy variety (same monsters that you see all game long).
-No chapter replay option in the main campaign.
-You cannot run... like
date:
what the hell is that?
-No puzzles.
-This is no "survival horror" game like we used to play on the early RE games and keeps the game into the "action horror shooter" mode.

Decent port to say the least! If you're a Resident Evil fan

reviewText: It was so refreshing to be back in the Resident Evil universe after a long break since the failure that was Resident Evil 5, and Revelations has done a magnificent job of reviving my faith in the franchise. Let me first state that I am, indeed, one of those purists that thinks RE1 was the pinacle of the franchise, and that the decision to move away from fixed camera angles really took something of the dread away from every corner and corridoor you couldn't quite see the end of. With that out of the way and taken as a given, Revelations is a good action game. Good, not great, good.\nLet's get the bad stuff out of the way shall we? As an action game, the controls don't really cut it in comparison to other fast-paced action titles. Strafing is a little too slow, particularly for those of us who are used to using strafe to get around corners, and made me feel like I was driving a fire engine rather than an athlete in a cat suit. The bindings are an improvement on previous games, but I still found myself modifying them to match the norm". There was a distinct lack of hoard activity

reviewText:
Resident Evil: Revelations is a departure from where the main, numbered series has been going, and the game works and is a fun, scary blast despite a few disappointments.

The game takes place in between RE4 and RE5, but the storyline has nothing to do with the main series at all. Aside from a few characters (Jill, and Chris) and a few organizations mentioned (BSAA, Umbrella), everything is wholly original making this game a good standalone for those curious about the franchise. The story is all about spies, bio-terrorism, counter-terrorism, and attempts to go into some interesting psychology behind the villain's motivations but it falls a little flat. The story is told with that same goofy, almost-not-b-movie quality that has become the staple flavor for the series, and for a tale spanning countries with some really fun twists and turns that tone works surprisingly well. Couple that with the game's episodic chapters and it feels like you're watching a low-budget TV show from the 90s, and it's great.

The gameplay really isn't anything too different than the rest of the series. It has an over the shoulder, third person perspective, shooting certain points on enemies will weaken them and allow you to melee them to great effect (I still think that Chris's fists are more powerful than shotgun blasts). For the majority of the campaign you have an AI partner following you around, ala RE5, except this partner doesn't need your healing items or ammo and can't be controlled by another player, which is actually an improvement for this game. Despite it's similarities to 5, the game actually made me frightened, which only the first game (the Gamecube remake) managed to do. The atmosphere is very well set up, and one of the main locations in the game requires back tracking, but it's done so well you feel like you're running hopelessly in circles. The most frightening, and challenging, part of the game actually has you search for a dead comrade, only to find she has been resurrected as a disgusted squid-mutant-lady, and you then have to hunt her throughout the games main setting, which is a creepy, derelict boat that sways slowly beneath your feet. This moment is when the game really, truly shines as you never know when she's going to pop out and scream in a girlish voice, found you!" Unfortunately the rest of the game is nowhere near as scary

reviewText:
Fan might know before playing, that revelations told series of event before Resident Evil 5 took place in africa.
Yet, Unlike RE5 that emphasize action, capcom's revelations clearly accentuate their ability to combine classic gameplay with modern 3rd person shooting.
If you are a big fan of RE previous installments and you like to feel alone in confined space. This game will be your bread and butter.
And for people who already complete the campaign, capcom provide additional challenges through raid mode.
For me, raid mode probably the most valuable gem this game had to offer. You can play multiplayer, collect weapon a la borderlands, add mods to enhance them, and many more. I spent 8/10 of my gameplay time on raid and i must say it is REALLY satisfying.

In the end, i recommend this game for anyone who never played RE before. You are not going to regret buying this game.
And for you fan of RE ? I dont think this review matter for you guys. You probably already add to cart" this game a minutes ago."

reviewText:
I don't have much play time on the PC version, but I did play through this entire game on my 3DS and played a large portion of the online before the HD version was released. Capcom, THIS is a Resident Evil game done right. To be fair though, I didn't mind RE6, or even ORC for that matter, but I'm probably in the minority here. Anyway, all the stuff that a fan of classic resident evil wants is here: excellent pacing, horrific tension, limited supplies (kind of) and all the cheesy dialogue the writers at Capcom could shove in here. I say kind of limited supplies, because you're given a scanner-gun very early on that allows you to scan enemies to create Green Herbs. The way it works though, is that if an enemy is already dead and you go to scan them, you'll get a minimal amount of points towards your herbage. If you scan a still-living enemy you'll get a load more points. You can also use the scanner to find handprints (RE games always have collectibles and, uh, this is it?) and secret pick-ups.
The gameplay is pretty much the same from RE4, but it's obviously a little bit more up to date. It feels familiar but fresh. The game also allows you to choose between aiming in first, or third person. I played with the first person aim and loved it. Give it a shot if you haven't, it's a whole different experience.
The story was pretty solid, for a fairly cheesy one. And I personally enjoyed all the nods♥♥♥♥♥♥ences to Dante Alighieri's Divina Comedia which I myself have read and very much enjoyed. However, that mission with the 2 random dudes that hold absolutely no weight whatsoever in the story? Kinda felt like padding, and it takes away from the almost perfect pacing of the game. I didn't mind switching between multiple protagonists, but those 2 goons were just, well, goons.
The game also has a co-op mode that I had put a handful of hours into. It's fun with strangers but even more fun with friends. It feels very different from the single player in the sense that enemies now have a health-bar, and power levels. If you've ever played Borderlands you'll get the grasp of it very quickly. There are tons of different guns to collect, including super rare/unique weapons. You can also modify your weapons with a plethora of different parts in single player and in Co-op.
Definitely pick up this game if you're an old fan of the series, but if you're new and looking for a solid entry point, go with RE4. And if you're interested in playing RE4 and aren't a graphics nazi, I highly recommend the Wii version. Best controls of all the versions I've played.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
For many people, Resident Evil 5 just wasn't scary enough. Others complained that it had too much action. Yet more said the game relied too much on co-op play, thereby negatively affecting the single player mode.

As if taking these concerns to heart, Capcom went and made Resident Evil: Revelations, touted as a return to 'survival horror'. They may not quite have succeeded on that goal, but this is a damn fine Resident Evil game. A single player campaign actually meant to be played solo, creepy settings, and just the right amount of ammo to have you worrying about conservation.

It's just all such a shame that so much good work was undone by Resident Evil 6...

reviewText:
This game is definitely for diehard fans of the Resident Evil franchise. I wouldn't say I suffered through the game, however, I did not enjoy it as much as I think I could have. That may be because even for an RE story, this game has one of the worst narratives. There are worse so...

Anyway, I won't be too negative since this is a port of a game that was originally released for the Nintendo 3DS. Instead I'll  plus/minus the highs and lows. Easier to digest the point of the review.

+ Hi-res texture upgrades are very welcome
+ Music and sound effects are excellent
+ If you're a diehard RE fan, it's more RE

- Story is uber boring
- Weapon upgrade system is lacking
- Movement is horrible considering the agility of some of the enemies and bosses
- $50 price tag. This is a $20 game at most

An Ok side story that I will probably not revisit, but did not hate. I can recommend this game but only if it's on sale and if you're an RE fan like myself, even though the writing in this series has entered comedy.

reviewText:
A solid entry in the series, Reveleations starts off great and evokes the survival horror aspects of earlier RE games.

However, those looking for pure survival horror (as I was) be warned: the game ditches the atmospheric scares half way through in favor of modern RE's fast-paced, action focused gameplay.

While RE's modern approach is not necessarily a bad thing, it would be better contained to the game's fun and arcade-y Raid Mode.

Ultimately Revelations' campaign should have remained methodical and atmospheric. Still, you can't go wrong picking this up. Despite its shortcomings in the second half it is one of the better (modern) RE games. I just wish the whole game let me play as Jill alone on a big scary ship.

reviewText:
A friend who I play with recommended this game to play Co-op. I did a bit of research on the game and found out it was a mobile game port, so wasn't really expecting much.

However I was pleasantly surprised how it reminded me of old school Resident Evil games I used to play on the Playstation back in the 90s. I actually enjoyed playing this game a lot, and have had some good co-op fun with it.

The game starts off quite easy, but the harder difficulties are more challenging .. so it is probably worth starting the campaign off on Normal or Infernal difficulty. The story is reasonably good and keeps you going to see what happens next.

Raid mode (the actual Co-Op part of the game) is a blast as you progress through the difficulties. I just wish that it was possible to do the campaign Co-Op like Resident Evil 5, I have no idea why they did not include this feature, maybe it would have made the campaign too easy .. who knows.

Lack of Co-Op campaign is really the only big downside to this game, so if you enjoy blasting BOWs with your friends at least you have RAID mode.

Recommended.

reviewText: While RE6 was a guilty pleasure, I can safely say this is a genuinely good Resident Evil game. There are a number of artifacts that remind you of this being a handheld port -- the episodic format mainly, but poor textures as well -- but this a step back towards RE4; less action, more survival horror.  Well, maybe not horror.  Nothing in this is scary, per se.  The weapon customization is excellent, and this game's arcade/mercenaries mode (called raid mode) is suprisingly good, being what I can only describe as a mini-campaign.  Raid mode is multiplayer if you want, the campaign is single player with an AI partner you'll barely notice because he does nothing and I'm pretty sure can't die at all.  The story is awful, but that's Resident Evil for you.  If you can get it on sale and liked RE4, you literally can't go wrong with this.

reviewText:
Campaign
really linear almost droll, but if you take your time it can be suspensful. The characters are the classic Jill cardboard and Chris cardboard. there are other characters they introduce into the story of resident evil such as parker, quint, keith, o'neal, veltro, jessica, rachel (barely), red hair dude (conan o'brian ripoff), and some other characters. The only one you atcually really care about is parker. parker is like a shadow of barry he acts like him. all in all the campaign was ok at best.

Multiplayer
What do you get when you combine diablo 2 and gears of war. you get the multiplayer that is what revelations brings you. you and a friend or other player play through scenarios from the campaign while bumrushing through hoards of enemies. all to progress and make you guy better. there are different rarity's of weapons red being uber rare. also you are given the chance of upgrading weapons to a make of 30. the multiplayer is what this  game was made for. i will say this at the very least if you do not like grinding to make your character better, then i wouldn't suggest to get this game for multiplayer. please note after grinding sooo much you will see just how much of a difference you have made in your progress.

reviewText:
I cannot believe I am saying this but this game is the first reasonably good Resident Evil game since Resident Evil Code Veronica.

The game's atmosphere is engaging and filled with suspense.
The monsters actually surprise you and put up a fight most of the time.
The story could be better, it begins shrouded by mystery, and when it clears up it reveals another political war.
The AI sucks, a lot. The monsters ignore your AI partner and go directly for you, and your AI partner does not do a thing. RE 5 AI was better.
The game is very short.

Overall it is the first game since RE 4 that brings the classic Resident Evil feeling from the first games. I highly recommend to all classic Resident Evil fans out there.

reviewText:
First thing first. The only real reason i would recommend this, is because i love the Resident evil universe. If you're not a fan of the series, don't even go there.

Starting off with the good parts. The story is rather decent. The characters are as lovely as ever and the not-completely-linier-except-it-is idea is a fun diversion from the regularity in most RE games.
I also liked the weapon upgrade system, gives a more changey feel and all choices are not permanent.

Now to the bad parts, the *WEAPON UPGRADE SYSTEM* is not permanent and feels weird for a RE game...

The *GRAPHICS* are sad, not as in bad but it gives a kindof dead feeling. The lighting is lighting up whole cupboards like it's a semi-budgettey game from the late 2000s. All textures who are about to move are semi-obvious to completely obvious.

The game suffers from *EXTREME CONSOLITIES*. The graphics is one of the clues, the other is the aiming. Even though we remove the aim-help, it's still jumpy, You can't aim properly when you're getting close to a monster couse even though it's turned off, the aim-help seems to kick and and prevents any fast or small movements of the aim.

THERE ARE NO REAL ZOMBIES! Just lots of weird blobby humanoids who are no fun trying to aim at with their wobbly heads and ♥♥♥♥ed up aiming.

There are *NO SCARY SCENES* where you know you're about to get ♥♥♥♥ed but still try to make it out with key-combinations, even though the rest of the game is console-oriented, this part which is usually the more fun, and mostly hated, part of the RE games IMHO, is left out.

*IT'S PRACTICALLY IMPOSSIBLE TO DODGE* it makes no sence that you have to time a turnabout to dodge, and you almost always dodge straight into whatever's trying to run into you.

But i still played through the whole campaign, and i actually enjoyed it. So the story is a pretty big plus, even though i am quite sure most people will not agree with me on that part. There are quite a few things that does not make sence, RE wise, but i suppose it's still legit. I want to believe.

reviewText:
I originally played this on 3DS, but I recently decided to check out this version since it was on sale and I'm cheap as heck sometimes. Anyways...

Resident Evil Revelations is known for taking the series back to its survival horror roots, which it actually does. Although, I still prefer Resident Evil 4 (which I'll also have to try checking out the PC version of), but this is probably my 2nd favorite in the franchise.

There's a bunch of plot twists, the enemies are sometimes decently challenging. I say sometimes since the 3DS version made me so used to standing while shooting, so this version feels like a walk in a park to me, except in that part where you have no weapons. Speaking fo which, I don't remember that B.O.W. being able to get its head out of the TV in the original version. Unless it was always like that and I'm just really fast when it comes to getting out of the room usually, nice touch.

The gameplay mainly has a system of primary weapons (guns), secondary weapons (explosives), and a dodge system which is easily abused when you know what you're doing. I'm still a bit rusty at the dodging since I haven't used it in so long, but you can generally just move forward real quick with the right timing and completely avoid all damage.

Ammo is scarce and enemies refuse to die, reserve ammo for when you need it. Either that, or just head shot everything. You could also knife everything or use your bombs. Yeah, those bombs have saved my lives many times. Especially the B.O.W. Decoys. Also, some bosses are down-right frightening at first. They aren't as scary the 2nd time through, though.....Except for the Com's Officer, he stops being scary for a while and then he shows you why you were scared with a nice chainsaw to the pelvis while a horde of undead fish people are coming to get you. I hate Com's Officer, but I also love him.

reviewText:
A perfect example of how a modern Resident Evil game should be!

Out of all the Resident Evil games, 2 and 4 have always been my favorites (Leon bias?) with RE4 being at the top. But even so, RE4 still felt like a step in another direction; a more action-oriented direction, which would later turn out be true, because of RE5 and RE6. But, here comes Revelations, a game originally released between RE5 and RE6, that takes a step backwards for the better, back to the classic style of Resident Evil, when the series was more about survival horror and atmospheric settings. And I can wholeheartedly say, that Revelations is quite possibly the best Resident Evil game I've played.

I was initially doubtful about playing Revelations, due to my general dislike of the direction the series had gone, and I thought that Revelations took the same direction as well. But boy was I wrong this whole time. Revelations takes the formula that made RE such a famous series within the horror genre, while at the same time improving the controls, making it far more accessible to newcomers, or people who hate the tank controls" and/or the fixed camera angles. It drops having to manage your inventory and worrying about space (apart from selecting at maximum three weapons to take with you.) And an improvement over RE5 is that you don't have to take care of your AI partner anymore. And not to mention that it features a story that is kept seperate from the numbered games' plot
date: allowing it to stand more on its own
recommended: without relying too heavily on the other games - which is really interesting

reviewText:
Very solid and fun if a little limited by being a 3DS port.


It may be a port of a hand-held but it still is a solid RE game on any console. The controls are much better suited to action style than even the RE4 set, and I wish RE4 HD had an option to use Revelations controls. Side stepping, moving while reloading, it just feels more natural.

Two things don't quite work however. The dodge mechanic is awful. Luckily you never need it because of the fluid movement system. The second is your handy item detector / enemy scanner. It works fine but is clunky and breaks of the action a bit, but it is satisfying to sweep a room and grab new items. Scanning enemies however wasn't as fun and would have been better off with a Bioshock earn bonuses system. Instead RE Revelations just adds a % per enemy scanned to a meter and when you hit 100% you get a health item. Useful but not engaging.

Two other things that stand out to me as complaints I've seen against the game. Variety of enemies and Graphics. There were just as many enemies as RE4 if not more honestly, because the difference between the cultists and villagers was clothing, and as for the Graphics I found that when when everything was put at the highest the game looked really nice. I liked the creature designs quite a bit actually.

reviewText:
I was thoroughly surprised by this title. I picked it up while it was on sale after trying the demo, wasn't sure how much mileage I would get out of my purchase. But RESIDENT EVIL REVELATIONS is a solid title in the franchise.

Though the gameplay is a bit hindered somewhat by the clunky dodge mechanic, it plays quite well; it's not as complicated as Resident Evil 6's gameplay mechanics, but is just as smooth, allowing you to strafe and move while aiming, and completely eliminates the need to menu surf for items. However, as I previously mentioned, the new dodge mechanic is clunky at best; to dodge an attack you have to move forward or back at a precise time to duck under a swing. It wouldn't be such a problem if a couple major bosses didn't rely so heavily on dodging. Otherwise you might find yourself crushed into a Jill sandwich.

Gameplay aside, the story is entertaining albeit predictable. Roughly half the characters are well written and performed, but several new characters are quite badly done and can grate against the player's nerves.
The atmosphere, though, is harrowing and claustrophobic, and the musical score is great.

Several episodes in the game come up a little short, but I finished the game feeling satisfied.
I recommend to survival horror and Resident Evil fans to give RESIDENT EVIL REVELATIONS a try.

reviewText:
A solid entry in the series, Reveleations starts off great and evokes the survival horror aspects of earlier RE games.

However, those looking for pure survival horror (as I was) be warned: the game ditches the atmospheric scares half way through in favor of modern RE's fast-paced, action focused gameplay.

While RE's modern approach is not necessarily a bad thing, it would be better contained to the game's fun and arcade-y Raid Mode.

Ultimately Revelations' campaign should have remained methodical and atmospheric. Still, you can't go wrong picking this up. Despite its shortcomings in the second half it is one of the better (modern) RE games. I just wish the whole game let me play as Jill alone on a big scary ship.

reviewText:
A friend who I play with recommended this game to play Co-op. I did a bit of research on the game and found out it was a mobile game port, so wasn't really expecting much.

However I was pleasantly surprised how it reminded me of old school Resident Evil games I used to play on the Playstation back in the 90s. I actually enjoyed playing this game a lot, and have had some good co-op fun with it.

The game starts off quite easy, but the harder difficulties are more challenging .. so it is probably worth starting the campaign off on Normal or Infernal difficulty. The story is reasonably good and keeps you going to see what happens next.

Raid mode (the actual Co-Op part of the game) is a blast as you progress through the difficulties. I just wish that it was possible to do the campaign Co-Op like Resident Evil 5, I have no idea why they did not include this feature, maybe it would have made the campaign too easy .. who knows.

Lack of Co-Op campaign is really the only big downside to this game, so if you enjoy blasting BOWs with your friends at least you have RAID mode.

Recommended.

reviewText: It was so refreshing to be back in the Resident Evil universe after a long break since the failure that was Resident Evil 5, and Revelations has done a magnificent job of reviving my faith in the franchise. Let me first state that I am, indeed, one of those purists that thinks RE1 was the pinacle of the franchise, and that the decision to move away from fixed camera angles really took something of the dread away from every corner and corridoor you couldn't quite see the end of. With that out of the way and taken as a given, Revelations is a good action game. Good, not great, good.\nLet's get the bad stuff out of the way shall we? As an action game, the controls don't really cut it in comparison to other fast-paced action titles. Strafing is a little too slow, particularly for those of us who are used to using strafe to get around corners, and made me feel like I was driving a fire engine rather than an athlete in a cat suit. The bindings are an improvement on previous games, but I still found myself modifying them to match the norm". There was a distinct lack of hoard activity

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Good old classic RE atmosphere
+ No annoying QTEs
+ Improved textures for the pc version

Cons:
- Getting a game going with random people is impossible. You can't just jump in and join a game in progress. You have to join steam groups and message/add people to get a game going
- Story and dialogue is B-movie quality but then that's a hallmark of the series

Preferred peripheral: Mouse and Keyboard. Although moving the mouse left to right repeatedly to escape when you are grabbed is very annoying.

Personal Notes:
The first good RE since RE4. I love the atmosphere and I had a lot of fun playing this game. Raid mode is the meat of this game and is really fun when you join a steam group to find people to play with.

Verdict: BUY!

reviewText:
I highly recommend this to anyone who liked the old Resident Evil days before 5 and 6. This one goes more to its roots with cliche lines with characters, weapons, story, and also it feels a lot like the Aarklay Mountains Mansion... even though you're on a giant ship.

Enemies walk very strangely and headshots aren't exactly the best option to shoot all the time either for regular zombies".

Raid Mode is a great addition to the life of this game and is extremely fun with a friend.
Campaign was done fairly well I thought it was good throughout but the ending was a little strange.

Feels like the game is worth $30.00-$35.00 as opposed to its steep regular $50.00."
